relationships.text: The project area is located within the Eastern Cross Timbers region, a north-south-trending zone of scrub oak woodland that coincides with a band of sandy soil

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The resources in the Eastern Cross Timbers and the Trinity Floodplain Forest would have been the most reliable and abundant source of sustenance for hunter/gatherers because of the variety of foodstuffs available in these zones during spring, summer, and fall

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Despite the presence of large mammal prairie species, such as buffalo and pronghorn, faunal remains recovered from archaeological contexts indicate that deer, found predominantly in the Eastern Cross Timbers and Trinity River Floodplain Forest zones, was the primary source of meat protein throughout the prehistoric period (Yates and Ferring 1986:27)

relationships.text: SURVEY RESULTS Findings from exploratory backhoe trenching and shovel testing conducted by Geo-Marine (Huhnke and Wurtz 2004) has characterized 41TR198 a as “typical flood plain site with multiple occupational surfaces containing hearth like features consisting of burned clay, charcoal, and fire- cracked rock (Huhnke and Wurtz 2004:iii)

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: When more than 200 g of < 2 mm sediment was obtained, the remainder of the sample was transferred to a 100 ml beaker and a 5 percent sodium hexa meta phosphate solution was added to break down the clays and to permit separation of the > 2mm artifacts and gravels

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Microartifact Analysis The dry coarse fraction splits obtained during the particle size analysis were passed through a suite of three sieves (8 mm (-3 phi), 4 mm (-2 phi), and 2 mm (-1 phi)) and sorted under a low power binocular microscope (Leica S8 APO) into gravel and various artifact categories (specifically burnt earth, debitage, fire cracked rock, mussel shell, and bone)

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Initial work at 41TR198 by Shanabrook (2003) identified two of these deposits in the immediate vicinity of the site: the Pilot Point alloformation and the Recent alluvium

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The Pilot Point Alloformation All of the prehistoric archaeology at 41TR198 is contained within the buried soil formed at the top of the Pilot Point alloformation, which was named the “West Fork Soil” (when not buried) or the “West Fork Paleosol” (when buried by recent alluvium) by Ferring (1986b)

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: All of the trenches excavated during the Phase III investigations exposed the Pilot Point alluvium, but a detailed characterization of this deposit was made using a column of bulk samples collected in 5 cm increments within Block 3, and this was supplemented with 5 additional samples collected in 10 cm intervals through the overlying Recent alluvium

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Within Block 3, the Pilot Point alluvium ranged in texture from silty clay loam in the upper part of the West Fork Paleosol, to a silty clay at depth

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The underlying horizon appears to have originally been merely an A horizon, but has since been accumulating secondary (pedogenic) calcium carbonate, and this zone consisted of a dark gray (10YR 4/1, moist) to dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2, moist) silty clay

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Although Ferring (1994) notes that in most cases the texture fines upwards through the flood basin facies of the Pilot Point alloformation, here the texture gradually coarsens, which is mostly reflected by an incremental increase in sand in the top 40 cm of the West Fork Paleosol

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: It is not clear if this represents more intense occupation or a period of slightly enhanced soil development, but this occurs during a period when the apparent sedimentation rate decreases dramatically (see discussion, below)

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: If the sedimentation rate here had been calculated in a manner similar to the other two sites (namely by dividing the thickness of the recent alluvium by 500 years (the period Ferring (1994) identifies as the period of deposition for this unit) the rate would be similar

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: , and slowed thereafter in the waning phases of Pilot Point deposition and the final period of West Fork Soil formation

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The Recent Alluvium Unlike the Pilot Point Alloformation, the Recent alluvium at the site exhibits significant textural variation as well as some bedding

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The flood basin deposits drape the core of the site and consist of clay loam, which contains a significantly greater amount of sand that the underlying Pilot Point alloformation

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: In a few exposures the sandier lower portion of the recent alluvium was absent and the A horizon formed within the more clayey facies was clearly welding into the West Fork Paleosol, and in these trench exposures the Recent alluvium was often difficult to distinguish from the Pilot Point in strong direct sunlight

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: No radiocarbon ages were obtained from the Recent alluvium, but it is assumed that this unit was deposited in the last 500 years, as has been demonstrated previously by Ferring (1994; 1990)

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The stable carbon isotopes obtained for bulk soil organic matter within the Recent alluvium show that toward the end of the period of Pilot Point sedimentation the organic matter shifted about 1‰ in favor of more arid adapted C plants, and then gradually drifted back toward more C plants 4 3 during the period of recent sedimentation, with the composition of the modern surface material being almost the same now as it was toward the end of Pilot Point deposition

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: These features include the boundary between the Recent alluvium and the Pilot Point alloformation on the west side of the site (at the eastern boundary of the modern Trinity River meander belt; denoted by the pink dotted line) and a series of arcuate lines (green lines) within the Pilot Point alloformation which are inferred to be scroll-bars that denote the general direction of meander migration (shown by the lighter green arrow)

relationships.file: Peter and Harrison 2011 - 41TR198 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: In order to more closely examine the integrity of the prehistoric occupations two studies were performed: 1) the depth distribution of micro artifacts in the bulk samples processed for granulometry was tallied, and 2) a suite of soil micromorphology samples were collected from the deposits for thin section preparation and microscopic examination

relationships.text: Burned Clay Masses of burned or baked clay are common at prehistoric sites in North-Central Texas and surrounding regions

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: Burned clay may be found as massive, fused deposits enclosing hearths or cooking pits (Osburn and Ward 2007), shaped or rounded nodules that served as boiling “stones” (Ford and Webb 1956), fallen wattle-and-daub structures (Boyd 2004), fallen plastered thatch structures (Drass 2008), intrusive or local material deliberately or accidentally trampled into a living surface, masses introduced into a living area on collected plant roots (Goldberg 2008), insect nests that can sometimes be considered as proxy indicators of human occupation (Boyd 2004), or as evidence of wild fires with no direct indication of human activity

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: Results of a recent experimental study suggest that much of the burned clay recovered in the region is likely due to the use of fired clay balls as heating elements in hearths or for stone boiling, a common pre-ceramic cooking technique, in an environment where readily-available stone is relatively scarce (Tinsley and Dayton 2011:111)

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: a few intrusive 20th-century artifacts had worked their way into the West Fork paleosol and the upper portion of the underlying Pilot Point alluvium

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: Its context at the top of the paleosol suggests that much of the Recent alluvium (at least the distal margins) was deposited during the 20th century, which in turn suggests that much of the West Fork paleosol was in fact exposed across the floodplain as a surface soil until sometime in the early 20th century

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: Geoarchaeological Summary and Conclusions Sites 41DL553 and 41DL554 are situated on the floodplain of the West Fork Trinity River

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: Geoarcheological investigations at the sites revealed that the floodplain alluvium consists of two allostratigraphic units, the Recent and Pilot Point alluviums

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: The top of the Pilot Point alluvium exhibits a dark, clay-rich Vertisol, the West Fork paleosol, which encapsulates the prehistoric archeological assemblages of both sites

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: The occupation of sites 41DL553 and 41DL554 coincided with the aggradation of the Pilot Point alluvium and the formation of the West Fork paleosol

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: The inhabitants of 41DL553 occupied a portion of the floodplain that not only was comprised of fine-grained flood basin facies, but in certain parts of the site were also comprised of sandier channel fill facies

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: Relatively artifact-dense zones at both sites occur below the A horizon of the West Fork paleosol, indicating that the most intense periods of occupations occurred while the Pilot Point alluvium was aggrading and the initial stages of pedogenesis were occurring

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: This decrease in sedimentation and channel entrenchment are reflected in the formation of the most prominent feature of the soil stratigraphy at both sites, the West Fork paleosol

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: Sites 41DL553 and 41DL554 provide evidence for both the movement of cultural materials within the soil matrix of the West Fork paleosol and evidence that artifacts have moved very little or not at all

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: 25-in screens) and micro-debitage (4-mm and 2- mm fractions of debitage recovered during flotation) show little difference in the frequency distributions of the size fractions, suggesting that the movement of artifacts up and down the profile within the West Fork paleosol is not pronounced, or that the vertic properties of the soil have affected the movement of all artifact sizes equally within the soil profile

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: 1 Summary of Phase II Investigations IES archeologists conducted Phase II NRHP eligibility testing for two prehistoric sites (41DL553 and 41DL554) located within the floodplain of the West Fork Trinity River west of MacArthur Boulevard in the City of Grand Prairie, Dallas County, Texas

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: As with many prehistoric sites within the floodplains of the Upper Trinity River basin, temporally and stylistically diagnostic artifacts at sites 41DL553 and 41DL554 are sparse

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: At both sites, the reliance on locally-available Ogallala gravels as the primary raw material for chipped stone tools is evident

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: Weathering of faunal bone is relatively equitable across both sites and indicates relatively rapid deposition consistent with the location of the sites within the floodplain of the West Fork Trinity River

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: The site also illustrated use of a variety of floodplain tree species

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: However, this is a result of variations in methodological approaches, specifically the intensive soil deflocculation and water screening that was implemented during this investigation, which resulted in a much higher artifact recovery rate than conventional dry screening methods used at other North-Central Texas sites

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2021 - MacArthur Reclamation 41DL553 and 41DL554 Phase II.md
relationships.text: To be considered eligible for inclusion in the NRHP, 41DL553 and 41DL554 must each have 1) contextual integrity (either horizontal and/or vertical) of one or more cultural components and 2) datable organic material that can be linked to vertical strata within the soil column, in addition to either 3) discrete cultural features and/or 4) a diverse artifact assemblage that can be analyzed and interpreted to yield significant data that will contribute important new information to substantially enhance the understanding of one or more of the research domains relevant to the regional prehistoric context

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Beneath the West Fork paleosol were grayish and yellowish clayey strata, and stringers of pea-sized gravels could be correlated to many of the trenches onsite

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: The substrate for a series of trenches dug into the south edge of the site encountered cemented gravels that likely date to the Pleistocene age

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: These gravels extend above the Holocene alluvial sediments onsite and provide some minor relief above the floodplain

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: In an area located about 60 meters north of the relic river channel, Block 2 exposed part of a deeply buried (180–220 centimeters below surface) ashy zone with abundant charcoal flecks and burned clay daub that occasionally retained impressions of sticks and small posts

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: The recovery of two dart points (a Trinity and a Yarbrough) at comparable depths of 90 to 130 centimeters below surface suggests that this area along the edge of the Pleistocene gravel terrace was repeatedly occupied during the Late Archaic period

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: HISTORY OF INVESTIGATIONS AT SITE 41TR170 Site 41TR170 was discovered in 2000 as one of two sites found during the surface and subsurface survey of the proposed SH 121 across the Clear Fork of the Trinity River floodplain (Seibel et al

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: The second site, 41TR171, is along a T-2 terrace remnant on the north edge of the Clear Fork floodplain and represents the remains of a historic ranch complex that contains mixed historic and modern materials, but lacked integrity; it was recommended as not eligible for the NRHP or for Texas State Archeological Landmark (SAL) designation

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Hicks and Company archeologists defined the northern edge of site 41TR170 as the south edge of the modern river channel and a hike-and-bike trail, and the southern edge of the site was delineated by disturbances erroneously attributed to gravel-quarrying activities

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: However, as noted below, no gravel quarries are depicted on the 1981 aerial photographs, and the ranch manager (Scott Walker, personal communication 2005) knows of no such activities occurring on this part of the site

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Particular attention is paid in the environmental section to the local geology and geomorphology, as well as historic impacts, since these have bearings on the overall site integrity and resource acquisition for the cultural features discussed in later chapters of this report

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Topography Site 41TR170 is located on the floodplain of the Clear Fork branch of the Trinity River at an approximate elevation of 180 m (590 ft) above mean sea level

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: The Clear Fork floodplain near the site drains from the southwest to the northeast in one of the rare northeast-trending portions of the river

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Numbers of ridges intruding into the valley represent remnants of Pleistocene terraces; one prominent ridge is located just upstream from the site and gently rises some 9 m (30 ft) above the surrounding floodplain

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: An extensive remnant of Pleistocene gravels projects into the valley immediately upstream from the site

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Undoubtedly, these gravels form the basis of the quarries reported by the Hicks archeologists that created the southwestern site boundary and the occurrence of gravels encountered in the lower deposits of the backhoe trenches placed along the southern edge of site 41TR170

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: The recovery of two dart points (a Trinity and a Yarbrough) at comparable depths of 90 to 130 centimeters below surface suggests that this area along the edge of the Pleistocene gravel terrace was repeatedly occupied during the Late Archaic period

relationships.text: HISTORY OF INVESTIGATIONS AT SITE 41TR170 Site 41TR170 was discovered in 2000 as one of two sites found during the surface and subsurface survey of the proposed SH 121 across the Clear Fork of the Trinity River floodplain (Seibel et al

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: The second site, 41TR171, is along a T-2 terrace remnant on the north edge of the Clear Fork floodplain and represents the remains of a historic ranch complex that contains mixed historic and modern materials, but lacked integrity; it was recommended as not eligible for the NRHP or for Texas State Archeological Landmark (SAL) designation

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Hicks and Company archeologists defined the northern edge of site 41TR170 as the south edge of the modern river channel and a hike-and-bike trail, and the southern edge of the site was delineated by disturbances erroneously attributed to gravel-quarrying activities

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: However, as noted below, no gravel quarries are depicted on the 1981 aerial photographs, and the ranch manager (Scott Walker, personal communication 2005) knows of no such activities occurring on this part of the site

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Particular attention is paid in the environmental section to the local geology and geomorphology, as well as historic impacts, since these have bearings on the overall site integrity and resource acquisition for the cultural features discussed in later chapters of this report

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Topography Site 41TR170 is located on the floodplain of the Clear Fork branch of the Trinity River at an approximate elevation of 180 m (590 ft) above mean sea level

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: The Clear Fork floodplain near the site drains from the southwest to the northeast in one of the rare northeast-trending portions of the river

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Numbers of ridges intruding into the valley represent remnants of Pleistocene terraces; one prominent ridge is located just upstream from the site and gently rises some 9 m (30 ft) above the surrounding floodplain

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: An extensive remnant of Pleistocene gravels projects into the valley immediately upstream from the site

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Undoubtedly, these gravels form the basis of the quarries reported by the Hicks archeologists that created the southwestern site boundary and the occurrence of gravels encountered in the lower deposits of the backhoe trenches placed along the southern edge of site 41TR170

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: More specific to 41TR170, detailed mapping of the site shows it to be on the Frio silty clay that is occasionally flooded (Figure 3, areas marked 26)

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: One interesting aspect of the soil map as depicted by Ressel (1981:Sheet 41) is the presence of small gravel quarries associated with Sunev soils that formed on the Pleistocene gravel remnant that extends onto the floodplain southwest of the site (see Figure 3, areas marked 43, 44, 78, and 79)

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Soils map fd the Clear Fork of the Trinity River floodplain at site 41TR170

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: There is also a rather large area of Arent soil at least 460 m (1,500 ft) south of the relic river channel and the middle of site 41TR170 (see Figure 3, area marked 7)

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Quite likely, some exploratory trenching to assess the quality of gravel deposits or trenching to control surface water flow may have occurred in the area of the site, but these disturbances have not delineated the boundary of the site as suggested by previous investigators (Seibel et al

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: As described in 1877, a pool of water at the headwaters of the Clear Fork was 200 m (656 ft) long at the site of Poolsville, Texas; unfortunately, poor land management decisions caused erosion of the Paluxy sands, and now this pool is completely filled in

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Conversely, in areas of dense gravels near the surface, especially along the southern margin of the site, aerial photographs show a marked decrease in the upperstory tree cover

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: 9 ft) thick caps the Pilot Point alluvium, and it too has developed a pronounced soil in some places

relationships.text: , Pilot Point, Sanger, and Aubrey alluvium) are not used, in part due to the shallow depth of the mechanical trenching and in part due to the recent age of the radiocarbon dates (spanning only the past 3,000 years)

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: However, further contemplation of how the stratigraphy of 41TR170, especially involving the clays and dense gravel deposits along the southern edge of the site near Trenches 18 and 19 and Blocks 1 and 3, relates to Ferring’s (1990) Trinity River regional stratigraphic model is under consideration

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: As discussed above, a large area of Ardent soils that represent overburden from quarry activities is located some 460 m (1,509 ft) to the south of the site

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Other modifications may include various bulldozer cuts that, when coupled with the marked vegetation shifts over the dense gravel areas, may have been misconstrued as the edge of gravel quarry operations near the site

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Throughout Northcentral Texas, Late Archaic period occupation sites are relatively common in the uplands, and a relatively large number of shallow buried sites are known from the Trinity River floodplain (Ferring 1990a:51)

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: 700 and 1200, and is characterized by sand- and grog-tempered ceramics and by Scallorn, Steiner, Catahoula, and Alba arrow points (Lynott 1977; Prikryl 1990)

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Even though microtopography is clearly evident on the landscape, no attempt was made to compile a topographic map of the alluvial terrace due to the dense vegetation cover over most of the site

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Burned sandstone rocks were numbered on the site maps and individually collected to provide maximum context data on specimens for possible lipid residue analysis

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: However, excavation of Block 2, north of the relic channel, investigated a thick ashy zone containing abundant small, burned clay daub and charcoal, with bones, shells, and artifacts, which tended to be about 40 cm (16 in) thick but sloped slightly down toward the relic river channel

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Many rocks were assigned specific numbers on the base maps, and these were point-plotted with top and bottom elevations and collected for further studies; special emphasis was placed on saving sandstone rocks for possible lipid analysis

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Specific material classes derived from this project consist of one continuous sediment column sample of alluvial terrace sediments and other sediment samples from features and occupation surfaces for flotation and fine screening

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Also collected were burned sandstone samples for lipid studies, other burned rocks from feature and nonfeature contexts, organic/charcoal samples, burned clay or daub samples, lithic debris and lithic tools, ground stone tools, bones, freshwater mussel shells, land snails, and historic artifacts

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Chipped stone lithic materials (tools, debitage, and cores) were sorted by class or implement type, stone tool material type (siltstone, chert, etc

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Baked Clay Analysis Baked clay (daub and burned clay) specimens are distinguished from vessel sherds by several indicators

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: If, however, no impressions are present, the fragments are considered to be unimpressed burned clay, the nondiagnostic clay fragments of unknown origin that could represent the residue of hearths or other open-firing activities, the remains of burned clay cooking balls, or even possibly indistinguishable fragments of architectural daub

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: CHAPTER 4 GEOMORPHOLOGICAL RESULTS Archeological site 41TR170 occurs on an abandoned or stranded floodplain terrace of the Clear Fork of the Trinity River in Fort Worth, Tarrant County, Texas

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Pre-Paleosol Sediments Based on information from the basal sediments observed in trenches at site 41TR170, three pre- paleosol units are present (oldest to youngest): cemented gravels (late Pleistocene), yellow clay (late Holocene), and gray clay (late Holocene)

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: There is an outside possibility that the yellow clay is a weathered component of the gravel deposit and that its radiocarbon age is spurious

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: At Trenches 18 and 19, a 16–26-cm-thick zone of limestone gravels overlies the yellow clay

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: after which the gravels were deposited

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: The gray clay unit is missing at Trenches 18 and 19, never deposited in this small area, and the West Fork paleosol occurs directly on the thin zone of gravels

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Gray Clay The basal alluvial sediment directly beneath the West Fork paleosol and exposed in most of the trenches at site 41TR170 is grayish brown (10YR 5/2) clayey silt and very fine sand

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: The gray clay and the West Fork paleosol represent a single continuously deposited body of alluvium without a discernible unconformity

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: In the present investigation at site 41TR170 on the Clear Fork, the paleosol is also present and is a cumulic over-thickened A horizon soil, formed by slow fluvial aggradation on the floodplain over a comparatively long period of time

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: The West Fork paleosol at site 41TR170 is dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) clayey silt and very fine sand; its dark color distinguishes it from older and younger alluvium (Table 4)

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Table 4 Sediment Data from Site 41TR170, Clear Fork of the Trinity River Floodplain, Tarrant County, Texas Sand (mm) Recalculated 2

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: At site 41TR170, no evidence for the post-paleosol channel trenching was observed, and the boundary between the West Fork paleosol and overlying alluvium is gradational, obscured by bioturbation (Figure 9)

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: The post-paleosol alluvium caps the paleosol in every trench exposure at site 41TR170 except in those few cases where historic disturbance has resulted in sediment removal, exposing the top of the paleosol at the disturbed surface

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: The post-paleosol alluvium, if correlative with other post-paleosol alluvial units in the region, may have been deposited between about 800 and 100 years ago

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: However, in contrast to the cumulic soil depositional environment, the post-paleosol alluvium likely accumulated during fewer flood events, but each flood produced a thicker layer of sandy sediment deposited on the wooded floodplain

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: Sediment Characteristics Sand, Silt, Clay Alluvium, including the West Fork paleosol, from two trenches at site 41TR170 was analyzed for texture, organic carbon, and carbonates (see Table 4)

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md
relationships.text: This relationship may be due to the presence of Trench 6 on the inside of the Clear Fork meander curve, resulting in less sand and more clayey silt deposited on the floodplain during flooding

relationships.file: Lintz et al 2008 - Archeological Testing at 41TR170.md

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster 2015 - Texas Horse Park.md
relationships.text: Masses of burned or baked clay are common at prehistoric sites in Northcentral Texas and surrounding regions

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster 2015 - Texas Horse Park.md
relationships.text: Burned clay may be found as massive, fused deposits enclosing hearths or cooking pits (Osburn and Ward 2007), shaped or rounded nodules that served as boiling “stones” (Ford and Webb 1956; Lorrain 2012), fallen wattle-and-daub structures (Boyd 2004), fallen plastered thatch structures (Drass 2008), intrusive or local material deliberately or accidentally trampled into a living surface, masses introduced into a living area on collected plant roots (Goldberg 2008), insect nests that can sometimes be considered as proxy indicators of human occupation (Boyd 2004), or as evidence of forest fires with no direct indication of human activity

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster 2015 - Texas Horse Park.md
relationships.text: No intact burned clay features were encountered during the current investigations at site 41DL72

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster 2015 - Texas Horse Park.md
relationships.text: Botanical Remains Botanical remains identified on prehistoric archeological sites in Northcentral Texas are typically confined to charred plant remains recovered opportunistically within the soil matrix during excavation or during flotation of excavated soil samples

relationships.text: Patterns of Dietary Diversity Microenvironments Utilized The taxa represented in the Broken Mammoth faunal assemblage indicate wide utilization of paleomicroenvironments adjacent to the site: dry steppe/ tundra (bison, elk, caribou); wetlands (fish, waterfowl, beaver, otter); and uplands (marmot, ground squirrel, Dall sheep, ptarmigan)

relationships.text: These analyses will require very specific kinds of data, including but not limited to: (1) a well-defined stratigraphic framework for the Pleistocene and Holocene sediments in the project area (2) a geomorphic model of landforms in the project area integrated with the stratigraphy, (3) a radiocarbon chronology for the sediments and landforms, (4) evidence of past environments, including pollen, mollusks, vertebrates, and soils, (5) a site-location data base fully integrated into the geologic framework as well as the biogeographic framework, (6) a chronology of the sites, including dated episodes of site use, (7) data permitting site-use histories: spatial patterning and feature associations, (8) data on site activities: tools, cores, debitage, and ceramics, (9) evidence of external contacts and intersite cultural affiliations: tool and ceramic styles as well as mineralogic analysis of stone and ceramic materials, (10) a set of analytical procedures to integrate patterns of intrasite variability with patterns of intersite variability, and (11) a set of research hypotheses and theoretical constructs to explain the observed variability with reference to population dynamics, resource availability, and exploitation patterns

relationships.text: • Settlement Systems Data pertaining to the reconstruction of settlement systems include: (1) site locations relative to landforms, hydrologic factors, soils, and vegetation (present and reconstructed), (2) site size, (3) spatial clustering and spatial coassociations of tools, debris, and features, (4) measures of site-use intensity, including artifact deposition rates, tool use and discard patterns, feature density and use patterns, architectural remains, and volume of food remains, (5) measures of site-use periodicity, including evidence of seasonality (macrofossils, molluscs, deer elements, etc

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Data bearing on site exposure and preservation control include: (1) geomorphic assessment of land-surface age and exposure period, (2) recent histories of sedimentation by fluvial and colluvial mechanisms causing possible site burial and concealment, (3) detailed soils-stratigraphic framework, and (4) evidence of post-occupation weathering and disturbance histories as these bear on site preservation

relationships.text: With respect to Quaternary geologic and environmental history, the bedrock geology of the Upper Trinity River drainage basin is important for assessing bedrock as: a) a resistive component of landform evolution, b) parent materials for soils, and c) sources of alluvial, colluvial and eolian sediments

relationships.text: GEOARCHAEOLOGY: FLOODPLAIN SITES INTRODUCTION Geologic investigations of the Trinity River, as well as geoarchaeological consideration of site formation processes indicated that the optimal place to study stratified and/or well-preserved archaeological records at Ray Roberts Lake was in sediments below the floodplain (Ferring 1986a)

relationships.text: In addition, we feel that more has been learned about site formation in terrace situations, and later propose strategies for detecting and evaluating favorable geoarchaeological situations associated with terrace sites

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Two of the sites, 41 DN79 and 41 DN81, are in essentially identical positions on a Denton Creek terrace of the Elm Fork Trinity

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: The other two sites (41 DN346 and 41DN102) are on terraces of Isle du Bois Creek

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Because the alluvium associated with Denton Creek terraces is almost always sandy, these four sites formed in geologically similar settings, at least as far as the terrace surface per se is concerned

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: As shown by discussions below, the site formation settings off the terrace surface are different, and in two cases (41 DN79 and 41DN102) provided better site formation settings

relationships.text: Artifact and rock densities are lower than at sites such as 41 CO141 or 41DN103, yet 41 DN81 is on a stable terrace surface, while the others were situated on aggrading floodplains

relationships.text: Nevertheless, these differences demonstrate how site formation processes (depth of deposit, soil permeability, slope) as well as cultural activities impact fauna

relationships.text: The lithic assemblage indicated on-site tool manufacture from local quartzites, local ferruginous sandstone and regional chert

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Late Archaic occupations are not well preserved, but occur below Late Prehistoric horizons on the terrace surface

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: CHAPTER 18 GEOARCHAEOLOGICAL SUMMARY GEOLOGIC CONTEXTS OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES Archaeological sites in the Upper Trinity River Drainage Basin occur in two principal contexts: on terraces and on/below the floodplain

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Lower site densities occur in upland settings and in colluvial slope deposits

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Therefore, any sites of Clovis and younger age (less than 11 ka), can occur on terrace surfaces

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: The vast majority of recorded sites occur on terraces, where they are most easily found

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Located on a Denton Creek terrace surface, this site contains Dalton, Plainview, San Patrice, "basal notched", Trinity, Gary, Dallas, Fresno and Washita point types, among others (Prikryl, 1990)

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Most of the artifacts occur in the sandy A horizon of the soil that formed in the Carrollton Alluvium

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Survey data from Ray Roberts show that 70% of the sites located during the ECI survey are located on the terraces of the Trinity and its tributaries (Skinner et al

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Study of terrace site distributions can provide important data on past settlement patterns

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Indeed, because of long-term surface stability, terrace site distributions should be useful to monitor geographic shifts in settlement locations

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: The ages of sites on or below the floodplain can be predicted according to their stratigraphic position (Table 18

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Because of poor cutbank exposures (especially along the Elm Fork of the Trinity) and because the alluvial units tend to thicken downstream, older sites should be increasingly difficult to locate in downstream floodplain sediments

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: The Late Holocene Pilot Point Alluvium is widely exposed in the entire drainage basin

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Along present meanderbelts, Pilot Point alluvium is usually exposed in cutbanks

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: At Ray Roberts, both Late Archaic and Late Prehistoric sites have been found in separate channel fills of Late Holocene (Pilot Point Alluvium) age (see chapters on 41 CO150 and 41 CO144)

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: 1 SITE AGE AND GEOMORPHIC SETTING, LAKE RAY ROBERTS Data from Skinner (1982) Survey SITE AGE SITE SETTING 1st Terrace 2nd Terrace Flood Plain Upland Total % Late Prehistoric 10 3 13 0

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: In distal flood basin settings, the Pilot Point Alluvium is thick, dark and clayey

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: stable surfaces with Pseudoburial Terraces: Subsequent Sites 1

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Feature associations usually clear; faunal preservation excellent to moderate, depending on age of occupations, texture of alluvium, and sedimentation rate

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: This pattern of erosion is most common on terrace sites, which, as described above, have loamy to sandy sediments that are prone to erosion under proper conditions

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Only when Holocene channels were next to terrace scarps would terrace sites be affected by this process

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Because the local floodplains have been aggrading during the Holocene, no large scale loss of sites on the floodplains has probably occurred

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Lateral erosion of sites along channels can only be assessed for the Late Holocene, and this has occurred mainly along present meanderbelts and in constricted areas of the floodplains, where this kind of erosion appears to have been most pronounced

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: The effects of sheet erosion and gullying of terraces is difficult to assess, although this may be a factor contributing to the very low frequency of Paleoindian through Middle Archaic sites in the project area

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Sites on terraces have generally high geologic visibility owing to shallow or surficial positions of artifacts

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Late Holocene floodplain aggradation would have caused buried of all older sites as well as many Late Archaic and Late Prehistoric sites

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: The majority of the sites known from the Ray· Roberts area are on terraces (Skinner and Baird, 1985)

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: As prior discussion indicates, terraces in the Trinity Valley are apparently all Pleistocene and have moderately or strongly developed soils at their surfaces where the sites are found

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Thus soil forming processes are paramount in understanding site formation processes in these settings

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Also, most but not all buried sites are associated with alluvial soils in floodplain sediments

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Because of the interplay between alluvial sedimentary environments and soil forming processes on floodplains, an emphasis on soils as part of site formation analysis must include reference to sedimentary environments

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: It is no coincidence that most of the sites recommended for mitigation by UNT were in floodplain settings

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Pedogenesis and Site Formation Specific soil forming processes have direct implications with respect to site formation

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Site Formation on Floodplains Study of formation processes on floodplains requires coordinated analysis of sedimentary environments and soils (Holliday, 1990)

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Within a particular environment, assessing the impact of floodplain soil-forming and sedimentary processes on archaeological sites involves consideration of several factors: a) the chronology of sedimentation (parent material deposition) relative to non-deposition and floodplain stability, b) the chronology of archaeological occupations relative to sedimentation and soil formation, c) the texture of the soil parent material, d) the length of time the soil formed and e) the burial history of the soil

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Overall, however, site formation processes are different for archaeological materials associated with cumulative or non-cumulative soils

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Synpedogenic burial associated with cumulative soils protects artifacts from erosional disturbance, carnivore· gnawing of bone, and active near-surface bioturbation

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: By contrast, rapid deposition, followed by floodplain stability and development of a non-cumulative soil entails different site formation processes; in this case, the shallowly buried archaeological materials are subject to more intense, adverse modification effects

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: For archaeological occupations that post-date deposition of the alluvial parent materials, greater pedoturbation and bioturbation is expected with non-cumulative soils, owing to greater age than cumulative soils with similar thickness

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: The timing of archaeological occupation relative to sedimentation and soil development determines the burial depth of the artifacts and features in a site, and their position relative to soil horizons

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: By contrast, artifacts and features within an overthickened cumulative soil (at the same depth as in a non-cumulative soil) are subjected to a shorter interval of pedogenesis, but may have been exposed longer to pre-burial agents (erosion, carnivore scavenging)

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: The main point for geoarchaeological investigations is that to understand preserved soils-stratigraphic positioning of archaeological materials, it is necessary to document patterns of pedogenesis and sedimentation

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Bone and shell are usually well preserved in the former and absent or poorly preserved in sandy alluvium that was deposited before ca

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Progressive soil formation processes that are factors in site formation continue, with additive effects, unless the soil is buried and soil formation ceases

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Field and lab evidence for relative soil ages can be used to assess site formation histories at sites of varying age

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: At41CO141 (Area 1), late Holocene sediments include several facies, beginning with point bar deposits and grading up to flood basin clays

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Faunal materials and spatial patterning of artifacts was excellent in the lower part of the site, because moderate rates of sedimentation hastened burial, and because calcareous alluvium improved bone preservation

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Higher in the profile, bone deterioration and artifact displacement accompanied soil development

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Site Formation on Terraces Wrt:h respect to alluvial pedology, the study of archaeological site formation on terraces entails a shift in emphasis from the dynamic factors considered for floodplains to progressive modification processes associated with stable terrace surfaces

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Prolonged soil development, erosion and bioturbation alter not only archaeological records, but also the sedimentary and biotic evidence used to reconstruct environments for the archaeological occupations

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Eolian or colluvial sediments on terraces are not considered here, although these are clearly important and, in some regions, common contexts for archaeological sites

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: For purposes of geoarchaeological study, archaeological sites associated with alluvial terraces can be classified as follows, with examples from Ray Roberts shown in parentheses: 1

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Buried terrace site - site that is clearly buried within alluvial terrace fill

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: These sites were occupied and then buried under the antecedent floodplain prior to terrace genesis

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Surficial terrace site -site that occurs on or near the terrace surface

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Antecedent site -site that was occupied on the active, antecedent floodplain, shortly before terrace genesis

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Subsequent site -site that was occupied after terrace genesis, on a stable terrace surface

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Buried terrace sites and antecedent surficial sites, because they were initially formed on floodplains, are subject to pedogenically related modification in proportion to their burial depth and to the age of the terrace

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Initially in the same position as floodplain sites, these are affected by modification processes following development of the terrace due to changes in groundwater hydrology and from weathering and soil formation at the surface of the terrace

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: The age of the terrace, holding other soil formation factors constant, defines how long modification agents will affect the site

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: At the Murray Springs Clovis Site in Arizona, weathering and bioturbation resulted in deterioration of virtually all organic materials in the terrace camp areas, yet spatial patterning of lithic artifacts was preserved (Haynes, 1981)

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Antecedent and subsequent surficial sites may be difficult to distinguish without independent control over the age of the archaeological assemblages, the age of the terrace, or both

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: There are several reasons why it is important to make this distinction, and why soils analysis is important in the study of surficial terrace sites

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Prehistoric peoples located their floodplain settlements based on prevailing locations of habitats; if these settlements are preserved as antecedent surficial terrace sites, the sediments, soils and depositional geomorphic features surrounding the sites yield information on the original settlement setting

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Therefore, for purposes of settlement pattern studies, the difference between antecedent and subsequent terrace sites is significant

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Analysis of subsequent sites should consider the terrace sediments, geomorphology and soils as important elements of habitat analysis

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: In other regions, and particularly for sites associated with horticultural economies and village settlements, terraces were often selected for habitation because of soil fertility and protection from flooding

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Because these sites are generally less than 2,000-3,000 years old, they are almost always situated on terraces

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: For these sites, soils analysis can focus on modification processes that are associated with the stable surfaces, including those related to human activities

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: For sites associated with earlier cultures, however, soils analysis plays a potentially more important role

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Because of deep burial of prehistoric sites below the floodplains, and because of good visibility of sites on the terraces, the majority of recorded sites, ranging in age from Paleoindian to Historic, occur in terrace settings

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Therefore, all of these sites are subsequent surficial terrace sites

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Site formation processes on the Trinity terraces are dominated ·by pedogenic effects, bioturbation and cultural disturbance associated with serial occupations

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Almost all sites above the Trinity floodplain are located on one of the Denton Creek terraces, or less commonly, on the Hickory Creek Terrace (these are "T1" and "T2" respectively, in Table 18

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Site densities are much higher on the Denton Creek terraces, probably because of proximity to the floodplain and because of better drained, sandy soils

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Among all terrace settings, however, the modification factors that dominate the character of preserved archaeological records in sites are soil properties and site age

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Sites that occur on this terrace show evidence of substantial pedoturbation

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: As for the Hickory Creek Terrace, sites of any age occur on the Denton Creek terraces and disturbance is proportionate to age

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Because of the antiquity of the Trinity River terraces, all sites on them are subsequent surficial sites

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Neither geomorphic position nor soil development can be used to predict the age of sites, and progressive site modification is controlled mainly by soil formation processes

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Because of a paucity of investigations in floodplain settings, and because of higher visibility, most published multicomponent sites have terrace settings; discovery of projectile points, ceramics or other temporally diagnostic artifacts is the usual means of identifying multicomponent sites on terraces

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: By focusing on aggradational settings on floodplains and in cut-off channels, a series of well stratified sites were identified and mitigated

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: The floodplain sites all exhibit good to excellent bone preservation

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: In terrace settings, by contrast, lithic artifact densities are uniformly equal to or higher than bone

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Overall, the densities of lithic artifacts are quite low in floodplain settings

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Comparison of these sites with mitigation sites at Richland Chambers (McGregor and Bruseth 1987) or Joe Pool Lake (Peter and McGregor 1988) suggest that similar patterns of low density floodplain sites are widespread, but that they have very low visibility and are usually not the subject of mitigation

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Those reports also reinforce the patterns of terrace sites formation seen at Ray Roberts with respect to assemblage mixing and poor/selective fauna

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Again obvious is the fact that dating and definition of discrete assemblages was difficult at multicomponent sites in terrace settings or where deposition was slow over the period of repeated occupations (see Chapter 18 and Ferring, 1986, 1992)

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: Indeed, it was that radiocarbon age and its context that led to the successful exploration for older occupation horizons off the edge of the terrace at that site

relationships.file: 00 Ferring and Yates 1997 - Geoarchaeology and Prehistory of Lake Ray Roberts.md
relationships.text: This is especially true for comparison of sites in terrace versus flood plain or cut-off channel settings (see Table 18

relationships.text: The guidelines include: (1) in disturbed soils, pedestrian intervals of 20 meters were necessary to examine all access, egress, and turnaround routes; (2) in undisturbed soils, visual transects (20 m) would still be employed, augmented with shovel and trowel testing of at least one cubic foot of soil; (3) no screening was required, but soil profiles were to be closely examined and the soil sifted by hand during and after excavating; (4) if cultural resources were encountered, all ground disturbing activities would immediately halt, and an alternate route investigated and clearly flagged; (5) the SHPO would be notified and the site marked for possible further investigation

relationships.text: These differences are interesting because the stratigraphy and soil development between these three sites is so similar, even if the exact timing of human occupation differs between the sites

relationships.text: CHAPTER 8 LITHIC AND BAKED CLAY ANALYSES by Arlo McKee INTRODUCTION Upon the completion of the data recovery excavations, the collection from site 41COL172 consisted of 21,500 artifacts consisting of lithic debitage and tools, FCR, ceramics, animal bone, and shell

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: In the region, the composition of the Uvalde Gravels characterizes the locally available materials; and consequently, a given lithic assemblage is often represented by upwards of 90 percent quartzite (Prikryl 1990)

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Given the relative frequencies of materials identified, it is obvious that the collection represents a sample of the Uvalde gravels that would have been immediately available locally during the time of occupation

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: BAKED CLAY Masses of baked clay, also described as burned clay, burned earth, or (with a layer of interpretation) daub, are common at prehistoric sites in Northcentral Texas and surrounding regions

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: When large concentrations of baked clay are found at a site, the materials are often interpreted as indications of fallen structures, especially in cases where many fragments are fiber- impressed, suggesting a measure of temper has been added to the matrix (e

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Many fragments of burned clay are also indicative of the byproducts of cooking techniques, such as boiling stones (Ford and Webb 1956), or are found as fused deposits enclosing hearths (Osburn and Ward 2007)

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: 47) SUMMARY This chapter presented the results of the analyses performed in the Geo-Marine laboratory on the lithics and baked clay artifact classes

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: With completion of the data recovery investigations, the artifact assemblage from the combined field seasons at 41COL172 had yielded 3,151 artifacts classified as lithic tools and debitage (n=856), fire-cracked rock (n=569), and baked clay (n=1,726)

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Two subtle peaks were observed in both the lithic debitage and FCR distributions, and one broad peak was observed in the baked clay distribution

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The upper occupation (Phase 1) is represented by an abundance in lithic debitage and baked clay

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: A second occupational zone (Phase 2) is marked by an increase in FCR and a decrease in the quantity of lithic tools and baked clay

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The FCR and baked clay collections were analyzed to determine the degree of FCR reuse and intensity of occupation, respectively

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The vast majority of baked clay was small and lacked fiber-impressions, which suggested that the baked clay was produced as a byproduct of cultural burning at the site

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Site 41COL173 yielded two diagnostic projectile points from intact deposits in addition to higher than expected frequencies of burned clay/earth fragments

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: One of the backhoe trenches on site 41COL173 was abandoned after observation of the soil profile indicated the area was composed of channel fill

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The main difference in the two sites pertains to the soil map unit within which the site is situated

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Site 41COL173 is mapped as Trinity clay frequently flooded

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: In addition to the written and photographic observations of stratigraphic setting, two continuous columns of soil samples from the entire exposed stratigraphic sequence were collected from the site

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: All other artifact classes, such as burned earth/clay, lithics, and FCR, were analyzed by Geo-Marine archeologists

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Table C-1 Eastern Wall, Unit 16, Block 2, Trench 2, Site 41COL173 Stratum Depth(cm bd) Soil Zone Description I 55-78 2AC Dark gray (10YR 4/1) to dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) silty, sandy clay; firm; blocky structure; few large woody roots; common fine to medium woody roots; heavily bioturbated with numerous fine vertical krotovina filled with very pale brown (10YR 7/3) silt and fine-grained sand that gives the zone a blotchy appearance; clear to gradual boundary II 78-106 3Ab Very dark gray (10YR 3/1) clay; very firm; strong fine blocky structure with clay skins on ped faces; abundant fine to large woody roots; increasing amounts of white calcareous deposits along open rootlet traces with depth; bioturbated with common fine vertical krotovina filled with light gray-colored silty clay; common large whole gastropod shells; few fine pieces of pale orange burned clay; lower 10 cm of zone slightly lighter in color being very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) III 106-120 3ABb Very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2); very firm; strong fine blocky structure with clay skins on ped faces; abundant fine to large woody roots; increasing amounts of white calcareous deposits along open rootlet traces with depth; bioturbated with common fine vertical krotovina filled with light gray-colored silty clay; common large whole gastropod shells; few fine pieces of pale orange burned clay The upper alluvial horizon matches the soil description provided for the Trinity clay series (Hanson and Wheeler 1969)

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The zone is characterized by thin interbedded zones of pale brown (10YR 6/3) to very pale brown (10YR 7/3) sand

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: A total depth of 60 cm was excavated from Test Unit 1, at which point the amount of clay increased and the artifact density dwindled; the lower 5 cm of the last level were culturally sterile

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Other culturally related materials recovered from this test unit include eight pieces of lithic debris, 22 bone fragments, 13 pieces of mussel shell, 10 pieces of FCR, and 19 pieces of burned clay/earth (including three pieces of daub)

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: These artifacts included three bone fragments, nine mussel shell fragments, seven pieces of FCR, two pieces of lithic debris, and 26 pieces of burned clay/earth, among which are three pieces of daub (see Table C-3)

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Test Unit 3 was excavated to a depth of 40 cm below the top of the buried paleosol, at which point the matrix became lighter in color and the percentage of clay increased

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: 2) – – – – – – – * = Abbreviation for burned clay/earth X = Overburden removed by backhoe; not hand-excavated Test Unit 3 produced the third highest frequency of artifacts among the six units excavated from site 41COL173 in 2006

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: It seems probable that some thermal event occurred either during or after the occupation because of the presence of baked clay nodules and FCR

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Artifacts recovered in 2006 from the hand excavation of the test units consist of three stone tools (two arrow projectile points and a fragment of an end scraper), 20 pieces of FCR, 10 pieces of debitage, a piece of charcoal, 67 fragments of bone, 25 pieces of shell, and 47 pieces of burned clay/earth

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The collections from 2007 consist of 18 lithics, 84 pieces of FCR, 85 bones fragments, 53 baked clay nodules, and 10 mussel shells fragments

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Burned Clay/Earth Excavations on site 41COL173 yielded a total of 101 pieces of burned clay/earth

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The fragments of burned clay/earth from this site are all under 25

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The 2006 investigations revealed diagnostic artifacts, well-preserved bone, and much burned earth/baked clay in a restricted area along the west bank of Desert Creek

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The baked clay from the 2006 investigations was also thought to represent daub from the walls of a structure; consequently, the site was initially thought to exhibit excellent contextual integrity

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The distribution of FCR and the nature of the baked clay clearly suggest that site 41COL173 is a very low-density site that appears to have been impacted by fluvial erosion

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Archeological sites that exist on static landforms, such as bedrock surfaces or ancient upland hilltops that lack eolian sands, can contain concentrated densities of artifacts and feature remains

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: For example, a prehistoric site buried by sediment within an aggrading river levee has a far greater potential for containing undisturbed deposits than one located on an eroding upland surface

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: , have occurred, because these land-disturbing actions only penetrate a certain subsurface depth and can be expected to leave features and archeological deposits below a plow zone or churned soil

relationships.file: McKee 2010 - 41COL172 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The best way to determine the condition and integrity of an archeological site is to examine its subsurface context through soil probes and exploratory test units dispersed across the site, and assess the level of soil churning, the stratigraphy, and the potential for middens and cultural features to be preserved
