relationships.file: 00 Crook and Hughston 2015 - Late Prehistoric East Fork Ceramics JTAH2-17-44.md
relationships.text: Plain ware, both shell-tempered and sandy paste/grog-tempered, are the predominant ceramic types present, comprising over 90 percent of the total ceramic assemblage

relationships.file: 00 Crook and Hughston 2015 - Late Prehistoric East Fork Ceramics JTAH2-17-44.md
relationships.text: A select number of “grit”-tempered sherds (n=504) were viewed under a binocular microscope (20-60x) to determine if the “grit” (sand) was inherent to the clay formation or was a later added product

relationships.file: 00 Crook and Hughston 2015 - Late Prehistoric East Fork Ceramics JTAH2-17-44.md
relationships.text: 1980), we have concluded that any locally manufactured grit-tempered ceramics on the East Fork used the indigenous clay sources without the need for adding any sand

relationships.file: 00 Crook and Hughston 2015 - Late Prehistoric East Fork Ceramics JTAH2-17-44.md
relationships.text: From this study, four major groups of ceramic vessel manufacture have been identified: (1) a plain, sandy paste-grog-tempered ware of the type found in Fourche Maline and Fourche Maline-like cultures to the northeast along the Red River in East Texas, (2) a shell-tempered plain ware similar to that found to the west of the East Fork in the Henrietta phase of the southern Great Plains, (3) decorated and plain ceramics of known Caddo types from both along the Red River as well as from the Upper Neches, Angelina, and Sabine River basins, and (4) a small amount of distinctly Puebloan ware, that, based on typology, mostly originates in north central New Mexico

relationships.file: 00 Crook and Hughston 2015 - Late Prehistoric East Fork Ceramics JTAH2-17-44.md
relationships.text: As can be seen, plain ceramic types, both shell-tempered and sandy paste- grog-tempered ware, comprise 84 percent of the ceramic assemblages

relationships.file: 00 Crook and Hughston 2015 - Late Prehistoric East Fork Ceramics JTAH2-17-44.md
relationships.text: Only slightly less common is sandy paste-grog-tempered plain ceramics

relationships.file: 00 Crook and Hughston 2015 - Late Prehistoric East Fork Ceramics JTAH2-17-44.md
relationships.text: The type Williams Plain as well as various un-named sandy paste-grog- tempered plain ceramics comprise this assemblage

relationships.file: 00 Crook and Hughston 2015 - Late Prehistoric East Fork Ceramics JTAH2-17-44.md
relationships.text: Slipped Sanders Plain ceramics account for 7 percent of the ceramic sherds, incised ceramic sherds of a number of types represent 4 percent, with punctated (3 percent), engraved (1 engraved), and brushed (1 percent) sherds comprising most of the remainder of the assemblage

relationships.file: 00 Crook and Hughston 2015 - Late Prehistoric East Fork Ceramics JTAH2-17-44.md
relationships.text: Sandy Paste/Grog-Tempered Plain Ware The most common sandy paste grog-tempered ceramic type is Williams Plain

relationships.text: Shell-Tempered Plain Ware While Williams Plain is the most common sandy paste grog-tempered ceramic along the East Fork, the single most common ceramic type is shell-tempered Nocona Plain (see Table 1), comprising nearly 50 percent of all the ceramics

relationships.file: 00 Crook and Hughston 2015 - Late Prehistoric East Fork Ceramics JTAH2-17-44.md
relationships.text: Large frothy bubbles were present in parts of the over-fired side while the opposite side was in a very friable condition not unlike sun-baked clay

relationships.file: 00 Crook and Hughston 2015 - Late Prehistoric East Fork Ceramics JTAH2-17-44.md
relationships.text: Most common are ceramics associated with the Sanders phase

relationships.file: 00 Crook and Hughston 2015 - Late Prehistoric East Fork Ceramics JTAH2-17-44.md
relationships.text: Types present in East Fork sites include Sanders Plain (775 sherds), Sanders Engraved (69 sherds, Figure 7), Monkstown Fingernail Impressed (221 sherds, see bottom row of Figure 3), and Canton Incised (three sherds)

relationships.file: 00 Crook and Hughston 2015 - Late Prehistoric East Fork Ceramics JTAH2-17-44.md
relationships.text: There are also 328 sherds of a sandy paste-grog-tempered ceramic that may be a variety of Sanders Plain in that they have a maroon to dark brown slip instead of a red slip

relationships.file: 00 Crook and Hughston 2015 - Late Prehistoric East Fork Ceramics JTAH2-17-44.md
relationships.text: Slip colors on sherds from Sanders Plain and Sanders Engraved vessels varies from red to yellowish-orange to maroon, dark brown, or black depending upon whether the vessel was fired in an 27

relationships.file: 00 Crook and Hughston 2015 - Late Prehistoric East Fork Ceramics JTAH2-17-44.md
relationships.text: Of note, one of the few complete ceramic vessels recovered from the East Fork was a Sanders Engraved water bottle found in a double burial at the Upper Farmersville site (Harris 1948; Harris and Suhm 1963)

relationships.file: 00 Crook and Hughston 2015 - Late Prehistoric East Fork Ceramics JTAH2-17-44.md
relationships.text: Sanders phase ceramics originate around the site of the same name in Lamar County and along the Red River, as well as in sites in the upper Sabine River basin

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: Distribution of terrace zones in the study area

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: Map of the terrace remant containing sites 41DN79, 80, 81, 82, and 101, showing limits of surface scatter for each site

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: All of these factors indicate that the sediments in the terraces in the study area were deposited by relatively small, low energy, meandering streams that periodically flooded

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: With regard to sources of lithic raw materials, the major source of chert and novaculite for the study area appears to have been the Cretaceous Antlers Formation to the west, obtained either from gravels eroded from it or by direct quarrying

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: Because outcrops of the Antle-s Formation probably existed in much the same area in Pleistocene times, undoubtedly some of its cherts were eroded and redeposited in glacial river terrace gravels

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: Another source of lithic raw material within the study area consists of limited deposits of surface gravels containing quartzite cobbles identified as Oglalla Quartzite or Oglalla Chert

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: Thus, the Oglalla-like material in the study area is presumed to have been eroded and redeposited in a glacial terrace deposit

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: Intermittent excavations over a period of 6 years resulted in the discovery of 21 "red- burned clay hearths" (Crook and Harris 1957:12) interpreted as firm evidence of human occupation

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: The auger was used also to gather a complete series of soil samples to a depth of I m (for most sites tested) f or future analysis

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: In addition to the general shallow tests and one deep test for soil samples, all features on the historic sites, such as depressions or cellars, were augered and/or test pitted to at least I m deep

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: As with the historic sites, soil samples were collected from one auger hole for every site

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: As can be seen from Figure 3-1, these five sites are closely associated spatially, and actually occupy the northern edge of a single terrace remnant which projects into the floodplain of the Elm Fork

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: and 41IDNI10I * As noted above, the five sites occupy the same terrace ridge on the west side of the Elm Fork (Figure 3-2)

relationships.text: Summary of 41DN79, 4IDN80, 41DN81, 41DN82, and 4IDNI0I As was noted previously, these five sites all lie along the edge of the same terrace remnant west of the Elm Fork

relationships.text: Temporally, occupation of the terrace began during the Middle Archaic period

relationships.text: 41DN99 Site 41DN99 is a very large surface scatter of prehistoric lithic debris occurring on a low remnant of the first terrace of Isle du Bois Creek at about 177 m elevation

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: It was typed initially as a microband seasonal camp, believed to have resulted from a series of overlapping seasonal reoccupations of the same terrace

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: The fact that the Harrell fragment was recovered from the brown sandy loam deposit, while both the Pedernales and Scallorn were recovered from the deposit of dark brown sandy loam shows Late Neo-American material overlies Early Neo-American in this portion of the site

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: Most of the artifacts were associated with a dark brown sand and clay

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: The soil profile and artifact inventory suggest that the northern limits of the most intensively occupied area of the site has been reached

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: One Scallorn point was recovered from Level 2, and may have originated from the greyish-brown sandy loam

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: As asserted above, there appears to be a correlation between the upper light-colored sandy loam and the Late Neo-American points, as well as between the underlying dark-colored sandy loam and the Early Neo-American points

relationships.text: Level 3 contained two sherds: one shell tempered and one grit It is possible that one or both of these originated from the dark brown sandy :his were the case, then the lower deposit could be Early Neo-American in 1-73

relationships.text: When FM 455 was gravelled and re-routed in the 1920s, and the Skelton bridge fell into disuse, the lower area was cut off from Pilot Point

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: Terrace occupation commenced during the Middle Archaic period as evidenced by the surface site of 41DN80, and continued through the Late Archaic period at 41DN81 and 4IDNI01, and into the Neo-American period at 41DN79 and 41DN81, with the tentative suggestion of an early historic Indian occupation at 41DN79

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: The terrace containing these sites provides a unique opportunity to accomplish these goals without the danger of mixed assemblages, as is often a problem with stratified multi-component sites in north- central Texas

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: As such, it will provide valuable data on upland resource extractive patterns of this period, q to contrast with the bottomland patterns as exhibited by sites such as 41DN81 and 41DNIOI

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: Although the site area has been affected severely by gravelling operations, much of the site remains intact

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: In addition, it is recommended that an exploratory backhoe trench be placed along the southern edge of the terrace on which the site is located

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: Because 4IDNI03 is a single component Archaic site, and because it exhibits good preservation, it will provide valuable information on floodplain subsistence strategies for this period

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: In addition, the site location in the floodplain is unusual for the project area

relationships.text: It is fairly certain that proximity to a variety of microenvironmental zones, such as waterways, floodplains, terraces and upland areas (Bousman and Verrett 1973), allowed inhabitants to exploit a variety of fauna

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: Floodplains: The animals characteriitic of this zone include toads, frogs, turtles, muskrats, and swamp rabbits

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: Terraces: Zoological elements include opposums, skunks, coyotes, squirrels, rabbits, and deer; many of these animals also are found in other zones as well

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v2.md
relationships.text: Upland: In the past, prairies would have dominated this zone

relationships.file: Whitley and Skinner 2012 - Recovery of Human Remains from Site 41DL8.md
relationships.text: The only comparable data come from the Sanders site in Lamar County (Krieger 1946:175; Jackson, Goldstein, and Krieger 2000) where 60 individuals were uncovered and twelve were in individual graves and the remaining 48 were in nine graves containing from three to eight bodies

relationships.file: Whitley and Skinner 2012 - Recovery of Human Remains from Site 41DL8.md
relationships.text: No locally made pottery is reported to have been found with any of the burials and Sanders Engraved pottery, a water bottle and another vessel, is the only pottery type reported

relationships.file: Whitley and Skinner 2012 - Recovery of Human Remains from Site 41DL8.md
relationships.text: However, the grave at site 41DL8 appears to be an exception since the associated dart points and the radiocarbon dates indicate at least two of the individuals had been placed in the ground more than a thousand years before the Late Prehistoric sites listed in Table 9

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2020 - Tenmile Creek.md
relationships.text: The deeply- buried Aubrey site, located on the Elm Fork Trinity River in Denton County, yielded lithic debitage and Clovis points buried beneath 8 m (26 ft) of Holocene alluvium on the Elm Fork Trinity River floodplain (Ferring 2001)

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2020 - Tenmile Creek.md
relationships.text: The discovery of this site suggests that well-preserved Paleoindian sites in North-Central Texas will only be found by examining deeply-stratified Holocene alluvium in floodplain contexts

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2020 - Tenmile Creek.md
relationships.text: Previous investigations along the West Fork Trinity River (Peter and McGregor 1988; Yates and Ferring 1986) indicate that primary contexts for Early and Middle Archaic sites will be found deeply buried within floodplain alluvium

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2020 - Tenmile Creek.md
relationships.text: Diagnostic artifacts for the period are similar to those of adjacent regions, although developing a sound chronological sequence of diagnostic tool types has proven difficult because many of the investigations have focused on terrace surface manifestations where early artifacts are frequently mixed with later materials

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2020 - Tenmile Creek.md
relationships.text: The Harrell site and other associated sites contain middens, house structures, rock hearths, storage pits, and burials, and they most often are located on sandy knolls or terraces overlooking river valleys (Brooks 1989; Forrester 1994)

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2020 - Tenmile Creek.md
relationships.text: If clay content was high and could not be efficiently screened, the excavated soil was manually troweled and visually inspected for artifacts

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2020 - Tenmile Creek.md
relationships.text: However, the number of shovel tests varied based on the amount of disturbance, exposed bedrock or culturally sterile soil, ground visibility, and steep slope present within the survey area, or if archeological site(s) are encountered

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2020 - Tenmile Creek.md
relationships.text: 2 Backhoe Trenching Due to the depth of the proposed impacts and the high potential for deeply-buried archeological sites within the Tenmile Creek floodplain, backhoe trenching was conducted across the eastern half survey area

relationships.text: 5 m (5 ft), an Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) competent field supervisor assessed the stability of the trench prior to recording soil data

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2020 - Tenmile Creek.md

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2020 - Tenmile Creek.md
relationships.text: Due to the plotted site location across the summit of the terrace landform, survey shovel test intervals were reduced to 30 m within the previously identified site area to locate and delineate the site more accurately

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2020 - Tenmile Creek.md
relationships.text: The site extended along the westernmost portion of the terrace landform, above the channel of an unnamed tributary of Tenmile Creek (Appendix E, Photographs 1 through 3)

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2020 - Tenmile Creek.md
relationships.text: Shovel tests excavated within the site revealed a soil profile consisting of an upper stratum of dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) gravelly clay loam to depths ranging from approximately 30 to 45 cmbs

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2020 - Tenmile Creek.md
relationships.text: The location of the site near the summit of the terrace landform has restricted the archeological deposits to the shallow subsurface, as little sedimentation is likely to have occurred at that elevation during the Holocene

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2020 - Tenmile Creek.md

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: As Byrd (1971 :5) notes, these gravels are often thought of as a soil component rather than as a mappable geologic unit They are generally considered to be remnants of a once extensive "blanket'' of channel-lag deposited by long-vanished eastward-flowing streams

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: In his interregional review of lithic sources Banks (1990:56) states that "Uvalde Gravel is an ubiquitous term that is applied to almost all relict gravel deposits on late Tertiary and Pleistocene terraces as well as upland interfluves left as erosional remnants of the retreating High Plains that once extended as far to the east as the vicinity of Fort Worth

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: " He also suggests that redeposited "Uvalde" gravels may extend much further into northeast Texas and, possibly, into Louisiana, where he suggests a potential relationship to the Citronelle Gravel (Banks 1990:57)

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: QUATERNARY DEPOSITS The distribution of Quaternary terraces is of great relevance to the location and potential preservation of archaeological sites dating to the Paleo-Indian stage (see Chapter 2)

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: The Lagow Sand Pit material received renewed attention several decades later when it was discussed by Crook and Harris (1957, 1958) in their report on the Lewisville Site in Denton County (see below)

relationships.text: These latter investigations included work at the Malakoff Site (41HE60 [HEnderson County]) where carved stone heads of apparent Pleistocene age were recovered from a gravel pit in a terrace above Cedar Creek (Sellards 1930, 1941)

relationships.text: Ferring (1986) argued that deep alluvial deposits within the floodplains represented areas of high potential for the preservation of prehistoric sites

relationships.text: Recently, an important site was discovered on the Elm Fork of the Trinity River floodplain below the Lake Ray Roberts dam

relationships.text: The Aubrey Clovis Site (41DN479) is a Paleo-Indian campsite which is situated in stratified Late Pleistocene sediments 7 to 8 m (23 to 2§25 ft) below the present surface of the floodplain _(Ferring 1989:10)

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: " Indeed, they further note that, based on the results of a lithic source survey conducted as part of their investigations, "throughout [a ll] the time periods represented by the Joe Pool Lake sites, the prehistoric inhabitants appear to have favored the exploitation of the gravel sources along the Trinity/Brazos divide, even though usable quartzites were available from closer sources located to the north" (Peter and McGregor 1988b:281)

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: Two sites discussed in the previous section, the Lagow Sand Pit in Dallas County and the Lewisville Site in Denton County, were each demonstrated to be much younger in age than was initially supposed, although the Lewisville Site is now generally regarded as an important Clovis-age campsite (see Previous Investigations, above, and below)

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: Generally, Paleo-Indian sites have been recorded in both larger stream valleys and minor tributaries, with specific exposures within the "second terrace deposits of the Trinity River and its major tributaries" (Skinner and Connors 1979:9)

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: One such site, the Aubrey m Site (noted above), is a Clovis camp and bison kill locality which is situated adjacent to a relict spring and pond a deeply buried context in the floodplain of the Elm Fork of the Trinity River

relationships.text: , fired clay fragments or crushed ceramic sherds), were also recovered from the Cobb-Pool Site (see Previous Investigations, above)

relationships.text: In many areas oft he United States where large stratified sites simply do not exist-except within valley margins-small, seemingly insignificant upland sites may be used to understand the broader settlement system and cultural adaptations (Dancey 1974)

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: The scientific value of such limited activity upland sites in north-central Texas is enhanced by the fact that no previous studies have been conducted on them

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: Except for the current work on the SSC, studies of upland historic sites have been relatively limited in North Texas, with the reservoir projects noted above accounting for most large-scale investigations

relationships.text: These sites provide the opportunity to study some aspects of settlement patterning in upland settings

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: Extensive studies have shown that in both prehistoric and historic site contexts, plowing and vertical displacement of artifacts--even in permafrost and soil creep situations-have only minimal effects on the horizontal distribution of artifactual materials

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: Similarly, it was proposed that if the local geology and geomorphology permit, the characteraation of subsurface cultural phenomena even on small open sites could also be productively augmented by the use of portable resistivity meters with on-board data loggers

relationships.text: Each of the 42 loci to be impacted was assessed in terms of the following group of parameters: apparent depth of deposits; type and configuration of associated landforms; bedrock geology; apparent width of aggraded deposits; proximity to recorded prehistoric and historic period sites; and contiguity to Uvalde gravel veneers, which are potential sources of raw materials for flaked stone technology (see Chapter 1, Bedrock Geology)

relationships.text: Virtually from the outset of this project, a series of interrelated assumptions was made by the original principal investigators about the relationship of prehistoric sites to Uvalde Gravel veneer deposits

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: Second, the site boundaries were determined a priori to be co • extensive with the margins of the surface exposures of Uvalde Gravel

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: For a variety of reasons articulated below, these assumptions are now considered to be tenuous at best and specious at worst Prior to July 1992, twenty-two prehistoric sites or components (41EL58, 4 IEL99, 4 lELl 06, 41EL108, 4 IELl 13, 4IEL114, 41EL116, 4IEL118, 4IEL119, 41EL155, 41EL156, 41EL158, 41EL162, 41EL177, 41EL179, 41EL180, 41EL182, 41EL185, 41EL201, 41EL205, 41EL207, and 41EL215 [see Chapter 5]) were defmed on the basis of the presence of"an area ofUvalde Gravel veneer with associated fractured chert nodules

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: While these factors alone suggest that there is no one-to-one correlation between modem surface exposures of the Uvalde Gravel veneer and the presence of a prehistoric site, they do not exist in isolation

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: Two other observations are offered on the use of modem surface exposures of the Uvalde Gravel veneer deposits in the definition of prehistoric sitdcomponent boundaries

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: " Future researchers in Ellis County are well advised to consider both of these points when modem surface exposures of the Uvalde Gravel veneer are encountered

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: iMlo absolute correlation between modem exposures of Uvalde Gravel veneers and aboriginal sites, it is equally apparent (see Chapter 7 and Appendices A and B) that raw material derived from some Uvalde Gravel outaops were used for aboriginal tool manufacture (McGregor 1987b; Mell7

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: Clearly, unless the data presented here and in Chapter 7 is erroneous, most of the Uvalde Gravel veneers sampled during the SSC field investigations were not suitable or preferred sources for lithic procurement This in turn suggests that these particular sources were not important in site selection considerations

relationships.file: 00 Yedlowski et al 1998 - Superconducting Super Collider.md
relationships.text: Taken in conjunction with the information provided above, it clearly suggests that only the more chert-rich Uvalde Gravel veneers in and near the SSC footprint were the most favored source areas for local lithic procurement Other utilitarian activities documented either in the SSC sites or in the examined collections (see Chapter 7 and Appendices A and B) include: bunting and related processing, as reflected by a profusion of dart and arrow points, a variety of"scrapers" and "knives," and perhaps other unifaces and bifaces; woodworking or shaping, as suggested by the presence of adzes, gouges, gravers, and perhaps wedges; plant food and/or ochre-pigment processing as indicated by the limited suite of ground stone artifacts and the presence of two pieces of hematite; leathe1u0r hide working, as suggested by both the "scraper'' assemblage and the presence of perforators; bone tool production, as reflected by the two worked bone specimens, some of the ground stone, and perhaps, several of the "scraper'' and graver types; fishing, if the Waco sinkers are, indeed, used in conjunction with that activity; and, of course, ceramic production and related usage

relationships.file: 00 Bousman Archaeological Reconnaissance of Aubrey Reservoir.md
relationships.text: Most of the sites are situated either on low rises in the flood­ plain of the Trinity River and its tributaries or on alluvial terraces of the river

relationships.file: 00 Bousman Archaeological Reconnaissance of Aubrey Reservoir.md
relationships.text: The site is located on the floodplain of Elm Fork

relationships.file: 00 Bousman Archaeological Reconnaissance of Aubrey Reservoir.md
relationships.text: Six microenvironmental zones have been delimited on the basis of the relationships between the biology, geology, and physiography of the region

relationships.file: 00 Bousman Archaeological Reconnaissance of Aubrey Reservoir.md
relationships.text: The zones are: 1) Rivers and drainages 2) Floodplains 3) Floodplain rises 4) Fluviatile terraces 5) Upland slopes 6) Uplands 7

relationships.file: 00 Bousman Archaeological Reconnaissance of Aubrey Reservoir.md
relationships.text: 2) Floodplains: This zone is represented by a southern hackberry dominated forest community

relationships.file: 00 Bousman Archaeological Reconnaissance of Aubrey Reservoir.md
relationships.text: Drainage within this zone is very rapid and the soils are either sands or calcareous clays de­ pending on whether or not it is a timber or prairie zone

relationships.file: 00 Bousman Archaeological Reconnaissance of Aubrey Reservoir.md
relationships.text: 6) Uplands: This zone has the same basic relationships with biological and geological components as the upland slopes

relationships.file: 00 Bousman Archaeological Reconnaissance of Aubrey Reservoir.md
relationships.text: The major difference is that the drastic changes and variations of altitude within the upland slope zone are not present in the uplands

relationships.file: 00 Bousman Archaeological Reconnaissance of Aubrey Reservoir.md
relationships.text: The varying utilization of the microenvironmental zones is hypothesized that zone IV, the fluviatile teracces, in par­ ticular the terrace projections into the floodplains, functioned most often as a base camp, while the other zones were utilized when the season and/or conditions best suited an efficient ex­ ploitation of the resources of a particular zone

relationships.file: 00 Bousman Archaeological Reconnaissance of Aubrey Reservoir.md
relationships.text: The environmental evidence to support this hypothesis is that: 1) The position of the terraces on either side of the river, is the midpoint of the zones; the river, floodplain, and flood­ plain rise are downhill while the upland slope and upland are uphill

relationships.file: 00 Bousman Archaeological Reconnaissance of Aubrey Reservoir.md
relationships.text: Also described were soil types, artifacts present, name and attitude of landowners, and the probable time period and length of occupation of each site

relationships.file: 00 Bousman Archaeological Reconnaissance of Aubrey Reservoir.md
relationships.text: Environment macro: P) Grand or Blackland prairie district T) Eastern Crosstimbers district micro: 1) River or drainage 2) Floodplain 3) Floodplain rise 4) Fluviatile terrace 5) Upland slope 6) Upland Site description -- discussion of artifacts occurence, area, soil, and any distinguishing factors of a site

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING The environment surrounding the Adams Ranch and Bird Point Island sites consists of the broad floodplain of Richland Creek to the south, and terrace and upland areas to the north

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: In addition to the GLO witness tree data, other more general botanical summaries of Texas, such as Kiichler (1964) and Gould (1969), as well as data on soils and topography, are employed to interpolate between the known GLO data points

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Martin The physical, chemical, and biological composition of the soil often varies considerably from one archaeological site to the next, and sometimes varies within the confines of a single site

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Because dif- ferent soil properties effect changes in cultural materials after they have been deposited during the course of archaeological site forma- tion, an understanding of the specific soils present at any given site is critical to its interpretation

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: For instance, the shrink-swell capacity of a soil and the activities of burrowing animals living within it can re- sult in the displacement of artifacts, thereby complicating stratigra- phic interpretations

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: In addition, an understanding of soil genesis can determine whether the site surface has been aggrading, resulting in the burial of cultural horizons, or has been eroding, resulting in the mixing of archaeological deposits, or has been stable, with insignifi- cant effects on the deposits from aggradation or erosion

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: This chapter presents a discussion of the soil and landscape fea- tures present at Bird Point Island

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: A detailed soils map of the site is presented along with a description of each soil type based on the sys- tem of soil taxonomy utilized by the USDA Soil Conservation Ser- vice (United States Department of Agriculture, Soil Conservation Service [USDA, SCS] 1975)

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Following the soil descriptions, the relevance of the specific properties of these soils for understanding site archaeology is discussed

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Pheasant examined soil profiles at Bird Point Island and identified traits characteristic of the eroded T-1 terraces found in the eastern end of the Project area

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: The Pleistocene terrace materials are devoid of gravel or any other lithic material

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: The Wilcox formation, on the other hand, con- tains a lithic member in the form of iron-enriched siltstone and sand- stone

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: For the purposes of this report, the A horizon also includes the eluvial (E) horizon which is the zone of maximum leaching from which clays and certain chemical compounds have been removed

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: The A horizon is also the zone of maximum biological activity in which the action of roots, rodents and microorganisms have resulted in soil mixing, often referred to as bioturbation (USDA, SCS 1975:14)

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: It is the zone of maximum accumulation of materials such as iron aluminum oxides, and silicate clays

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: The C horizon lies beneath the B horizon and is the zone of unconsolidated sands, silts, and clays which have had the least exposure to climatic and biological agents

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Among the soils recognized at Bird Point Island, the argillic horizon and the calcic horizon are important for classification

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: An argillic horizon is an illuvial zone in which silicate clays have accumulated

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: SOIL DESCRIPTION Examination of the natural soil profile was conducted using north- south and east-west line transects across the knoll on which the site is located

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Six different soil classifications at the subgroup level were recog- nized based on the observations made at the site

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Distribution of soils across the terrace at Bird Point Island

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: This type of soil is often found on archaeological sites and is referred to as a midden in the archaeological literature

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: ARCHAEOLOGICAL IMPLICATIONS INTERPRETATION OF STRATIGRAPHY The nature of soil genesis and the physical properties of the A and B horizons at Bird Point Island are of great importance for inter- preting the nature of cultural stratigraphy

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: The soils present on the knoll were formed during the late Pleistocene, long before the first human occupation took place

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Consequently, debris deposited during various occupations of the site have become mixed together in the sandy loam A horizon

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Instead, most vertical separation of artifacts, with the exception of features excavated into the soil, is due to bioturbation

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: In recent years, archaeologists have devoted much attention to the role of soil-mixing processes in the formation of the archaeological record, For example, Wood and Johnson (1978:317) discussed the effects upon archaeological sites of pedoturbation resulting from plant and animal activity, freezing and thawing, mass wasting (soil creep), swelling and shrinking of clays, growth and wasting of salts, erosion, and earthquakes

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: (1974) assumed that artifacts found at greater depths had been covered with alluvium which had been subsequently reoccupied, resulting in the stratification of the artifacts

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: i4 The principal effect of bioturbation is the gradual vertical dis- placement of artifacts downward through the soil

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: At sites associated with Lake Limestone, Prewitt (1975:35) observed a gross separa- tion of Archaic and Late Prehistoric artifacts with some overlap of vertical proveniences in the sandy deposit

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Subsequent geomorphological analysis by Byrd (1979:27 3-300) demonstrated that alluviation was partially responsible for the vertical separation of artifacts at some sites on floodplain knolis, but that the mixing effects of bioturbation were still amajor influence on the vertical distribution of artifacts at most sites

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: In many cases artifacts are found directly on the clay B horizon

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: In addition, they noted variability in artifact movement which was related to the amount of time available for any given artifact to move through the soil

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: For example, hearths are usually darkened by charcoal remnants and also may be marked by oxidized clay as a result of burning

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Post holes which filled with organically enriched midden soil are quite distinct, whereas those dug in areas without midden development are often difficult to see

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: These artifacts would have moved into the soil through natural disturbances, probably caused in large part by the burrowing of pocket gophers

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Most cultural features at Bird Point Island represent pits dug into the soil for a variety of functions and‘most of these were filled with the dark organically enriched sandy loam that comprises the A horizon

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: The implication of soils data for the presence of interpretable stratigraphy and the identification of chronological levels is that no interpretable cultural stratigraphy is present, except inside Feature | which was sequentially filled and reused a various points throughout prehistory

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: _ Finally, the different soils present at the site have different poten- tials for the preservation of bone and mussel shell

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: One of the major goals of the testing program at Bird Point Island was to determine whether the large depression along the western slope of the terrace was the result of erosion or of cultural activity

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: The test units south of the pit also exhibited dark soil color, a characteristic of midden development, and higher densities of arrow points and ceramics

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: On the other hand, a relative lack of dark soil color, arrow points, and ceramics, coupled with a higher density of dart points, was observed on the northern half of the terrace

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: This suggested that a less inten- sive Archaic occupation occurred on the northern portion of the terrace

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Most of the excavated soil was dry screened through 1/4 in (6 mm) mesh to recover artifacts

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Prior to the start of Season II, some Project funds were expended for the construction of a pond in the floodplain west of the site

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Pumps were purchased, and a work area for water screening and artifact processing was constructed along the western slope of the terrace

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Study of the first problem sought to relate the archaeological deposits found across the terrace to the occupations recognized in the strata of Feature 1

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Also, the general outline of the midden on the south half of the site was visible, as was a small patch of darker soil on the north part of the site which was later determined to be of cultural origin (see Chapter 11)

relationships.text: MUNSELL COLOR READINGS As soon as the controlled surface collection was completed, the same 5 m grid points were sampled for soil color in an effort to de- lineate midden boundaries

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Control Trench 1 was dug to examine an area of high soil conductivity, the opposite of the conditions found over cultural features

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: The vertical distribution of artifacts in these trenches and others across the site reflect the fact that all artifacts were originally depos- ited on the present ground surface and then worked into the soil by means of bioturbation and plowing, or prehistoric excavation of pits (see Chapter 2)

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: The provenience information was written on surveyor’s flagging and placed in the soil prior to transport so that the flagging was dumped into the screen with the soil and remained in the screen with the artifacts during drying

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Soil samples were collected from the bottom of each unit immedi- ately above the interface of the A and B horizons and beneath the plow zone

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: This procedure insured that the color of the soil collected was unaltered by the leaching of organic matter in the plow zone or the inclusion of yellowish brown sandy clay from the B horizon

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: The soil color from the units was used to produce more detailed maps for greater definition of small middens around houses and activity areas

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Crew members proceeded with caution during the excavation of House 1, searching for the slightest change in soil color or artifact density that might mark the presence of cultural features

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: In addition, nearly 1,800 m3 of topsoil were removed by machinery to provide an unobstructed view of all features present at the site, once the systematic sample of the A horizon was com- - pleted

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Aside from the vast quantity of soil excavated at the site, Bird Point Island also received the most attention with respect to the use of remote sensing techniques

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: A total of 293,620 artifacts was recovered by the 1/4 in (6 mm) mesh used to screen mast of the soil (Table 3-4)

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: On the other hand, the artifact may have been present in the soil before the feature was dug and included accidentally when the feature was backfilled (secondary deposition)

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: For instance, movement of artifacts by erosion or chuming of the soil by means of bioturbation can cause artifacts unrelated to feature function to enter into the feature fill

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Likewise, fire cracked rock and baked clay are indicators of features subjected to heat, such as hearths

relationships.text: The principal attribute of hearths is evidence of intense burning marked by the presence of burned clay, charcoal, and in some cases by fire cracked rock

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Either these artifacts had been deposited in the soil before the features were dug, or they were deposited after the feature was filled and entered into the fill as a result of natural soil mixing processes

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: For example, Feature 103, a hearth containing oxidized clay and some fire cracked rock, correlated highly with Features 112 and 113

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md

relationships.text: Whereas Factor 1 includes cremations, hearths, and post holes, Factor 4 contains storage pits and post holes, mainly features with low fire cracked rock and baked clay content, associated with the village occupation (Figure 4-7b)

relationships.text: The depth of the midden and the gradually increasing depth of the sandy clay B horizon, from shallow outside the house to deep inside the house, originally led to the hypothesis that the structure was semi-subterranean

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: The dark midden soil and episodes of redigging probably account for the irregular shapes of storage pits and the difficulty experienced in finding them

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: However, examination of the literature shows that few houses have been found: the presence of houses has only been inferred on the basis of baked clay concentrations at sites such as Farmersville on Pilot Grove Creek (Stephenson 1949a:30) and at the Hogge Bridge and Branch sites along the East Fork of the Trinity River (Stephenson 1949a:38-40)

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: , Regional Soil Scientist for the USDA Soil Conservation Service, examined the profile of Feature 1 and helped isolate three major soil zones

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: The term zone is used here rather than stratum because there is no true stratigraphy in the traditional sense of gradual accumulation of distinct soil layers like those found on floodplain sites

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Zone 1 is comprised of fine sandy loam and is the most striking aspect of this profile, being characterized by a dark midden layer within the upper 40-80 cm of the pit

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: This dark soil (10YR3/1) is virtually nonexistent in undisturbed settings with similar parent material, relief, vegetation, and climate, and is directly relatable to human occupation and the addition of tremendous amounts of organic matter resulting from human behavior

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Zone 2 is comprised primarily of very dark grayish brown (10YR3/2) and dark grayish brown (10YR3/3) fine sandy loam sediments with lighter colored disturbances ranging from 10YR4/3 to 10YR5/4

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Zone 2 differs from Zone 3 in its darker soil color and higher concentration of iron, both of which apparently leached out of Zone 1

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: In fact, Zones 2 and 3 may represent a single fill episode in which soil color and changes in chemical composition have affected only the upper portion of the fill, creating the impression of two separate layers

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Zone 3 is characterized by a jumbled mixture of soil colors, including: brown (10YR4/3), yellow (10YR7/6), yellowish brown (10YR5/4), and even yellowish red (SYR5/8)

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: In addition to variation in color, Zone 3 is very heterogeneous with respect to texture and has characteristics which suggest that it was part of the Bt (argillic) horizon of the original undisturbed soil profile

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: The boundary between Zone 3 and the undisturbed C horizon subsoil is irregular, but quite abrupt

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: In addition, a fairly continuous zone of reddish staining occurs directly above and roughly parallel to the undisturbed terrace sediments

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Numerous rodent burrows were observed within Zone 3, where darker soil from the upper zones filtered down to fill in the burrows

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Organic enrichment of feature fill is limited to the upper 80 cm of feature fill (Zone 1) which formed gradually as a result of colluvial deposition of surrounding A horizon soil

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Laboratory analysis of chemical composition and soil particle size provides additional information concerning the processes responsible for the creation of Zones 1 through 3

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: The depth of the A horizon soil observed in the 50 x 50 cm units dug upslope from Feature 1 was only 10 to 20 cm, whereas the depth ranged from 30 to 40 cm elsewhere on the site

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: This suggests that erosion washed soil downslope into the pit which gradually filled the depression to its current level, and created Zone 1

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: Although it is possible that a greater degree of activity occurred around the outer edge of the pit, it seems more likely that the increase in density is a result of soil being removed by slopewash from the upslope part of the midden and redeposited within Feature 1

relationships.file: 00 Bruseth and Martin 1987- Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch.md
relationships.text: This effectively removed some of the A horizon soil, leaving a higher content of artifacts per unit volume upslope, and Depth ical Zone Nusaber oH $

relationships.text: However, no pit was observed due to the darkness of the midden soil

relationships.text: Alluvium: Clastic (detrital) material deposited by a channelized, flowing stream, including material deposited outside of the channel during overbank flooding

relationships.file: 00 Abbott 2011 - Geoarch in North Central Texas A Framework.md
relationships.text: Such minerals may have either formed by silicate weathering higher in the profile or been deposited as clay minerals in the first place, but must exhibit significant illuvial accumulation of clays translocated from overlying horizons to qualify as argillic; clay–rich primary deposits do not qualify

relationships.file: 00 Abbott 2011 - Geoarch in North Central Texas A Framework.md
relationships.text: Concretion: A product of localized mineral precipitation, commonly in the soil zone or in marine sediments

relationships.file: 00 Abbott 2011 - Geoarch in North Central Texas A Framework.md
relationships.text: Leaching: Removal of soluble components from a soil due to percolating water

relationships.file: 00 Abbott 2011 - Geoarch in North Central Texas A Framework.md
relationships.text: Nodule: A product of localized mineral precipitation, commonly in the soil zone or in marine sediments

relationships.file: 00 Abbott 2011 - Geoarch in North Central Texas A Framework.md
relationships.text: Common nodules formed in the soil zone include materials made of carbonate compounds, ferric compounds, manganese compounds, and (in locations where weathering is intense) siliceous compounds

relationships.file: 00 Abbott 2011 - Geoarch in North Central Texas A Framework.md
relationships.text: Phreatic Water: Water that occurs in the saturated zone of a soil, sediment or rock; synonymous with ground water

relationships.file: 00 Abbott 2011 - Geoarch in North Central Texas A Framework.md
relationships.text: Rhizoconcretion: A concretion formed in the soil zone, usually elongate and subvertically oriented, that represents laminar precipitation of mineral matter as an irregular tubule surrounding a root

relationships.file: 00 Abbott 2011 - Geoarch in North Central Texas A Framework.md
relationships.text: Rip–up clast: Informal term for gravel–sized clasts of mud or clay that have been eroded from a fine–grained bed by flood scour and deposited as clasts in coarser flood or channel deposits

relationships.file: 00 Abbott 2011 - Geoarch in North Central Texas A Framework.md
relationships.text: Also sometimes termed mud balls or clay balls, but should not be confused with the low–fired archeological artifacts referred to by the same terms that were used as a thermal substitute for rock in areas with little bedrock available

relationships.text: Most of the pebbles (roughly 65%) are fairly small and are composed of dark purple or maroon sandstone much like that exposed on the valley side west of site E (probably part of the lower Pawpaw formation)

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: No gravel beds were observed at site B, but they may have been obscured by slope slump into the gravel pits

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: The upper three layers at site B may be Holocene in age and may represent continued erosion of the surrounding uplands

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: The light gray, orange-mottled clay observed at sites A and B also is present at site C (Figure 3-6)

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: At site C, the clay does not appear to contain as many pebbles or calcite crystals as at either A or B, nor was any organic material noted

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Underlying these units is a zone of fine grained, well sorted sand which contains numerous pebbles

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: The contact between this sand and the gravel bed is quite sharp, as are most of the contacts at this site

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Unlike the first three locations, sites F and G are dominated by sands and gravels (Figure 3-7)

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Site I is again dominated by sand and gravel (Figure 3-11)

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: The site has numerous, prominant gravel filled channels and many cross-bedded channel sandstones

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Sites J, K, and L also are dominated by coarser clastics although there is some of the orange mottled gray clay so prevalent at sites A, B, and C (Figure 3-12)

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Both of these last two units have been cut by the gravel channels (this is best seen at site K), which are up to 1

relationships.text: SITE E Sandstone, brick red, fine
