relationships.text: Site M consists of the badly eroded remnants of a portion of T2 terrace

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: 2 All of these factors indicate that the sediments in the terraces in the study area were deposited by small- to medium-sized, low to moderate energy, meandering streams that periodically flooded

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: The deposits seem to indicate that the streams were fairly swift and clear with a number of new gravel point bars and gravel islands

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Some of the gravels at sites F, I, M, and D are exceptions

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: the horizontally layered, thin bedded sands at sites C and E which are very suggestive of transverse bar deposits in a braided stream environment; and 9

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: the cross-bedded sands at site I and the general bars at site F that suggest a meandering stream system with moderately deep channels and continuous water flow

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Army Corps of Engineers at the Lake Ray Roberts damsite seem to confirm that the bulk of the TO terrace is composed of dark colored clays with minor amounts of silt and sand (USCOE 1976)

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: This layer of sand and pebbles may have been deposited during the flooding at the end of TI deposition when the Elm Fork of the Trinity River was actively down-cutting its channel

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: To summarize, the TO terrace is composed primarily of overbank deposits of a river system very similar to the one now present in the Lake Ray Roberts area as opposed to the Pleistocene terraces which were deposited by a combination of braided stream systems that criss-crossed a wide, marshy river valley on the west and meandering streams with well-defined channels that crossed a well- drained area on the east

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Sites younger than this are likely to occur on or near the TI terrace surface, or in or on the TO terrace, with the TI surface probably being the most probable location

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Since outcrops of the Antlers Formation probably existed in much the same area in Pleistocene times, undoubtedly some of its cherts were eroded and redeposited in glacial river terrace gravels

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Another source of lithic raw material within the study area consists of limited deposits of surface gravels containing quartzite cobbles identified as Oglalla Quartzite or Oglalla Chert

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Thus, the Oglalla-like material in the study area is presumed to have been eroded and redeposited in a glacial terrace deposit

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: To conclude, it seems clear that the bulk of early man sites will probably be found in the eastern portion of the Lake Ray Roberts area, either on the TI terrace or in the eroded remnants of the T2 terrace

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Intermittent excavations over a period of 6 years within a borrow pit associated with the construction of the Garza-Little Elm Reservoir resulted in the discovery of 21 "red-burned clay hearths" (Crook and Harris 1957:12)

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Geologically, the site is located on what has been identified as the T2 terrace with a pre-Late Wisconsin date

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: The placement of the site (and the terrace) in an interglacial period accords well with the radiocarbon dates, but not with the human artifacts

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Questions have since been raised regarding whether or not the burned clay features were actually human hearths (Heizer and Brooks 1965), and the possibility that the Clovis point was planted (Heizer 1974)

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Sites of the Henrietta focus were generally described as being located on terraces of both large and small streams, and varying in size (Suhm et al

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: McCormick (1976:44) notes that some seasonal campsites occur on the lower terraces along creeks or rivers at points where they intersect with secondary drainages

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: However, it was expected that other seasonal campsites would be located closer to the river and may have been buried in the floodplain

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: It was hypothesized that smaller, more limited-occupation campsites and special-function sites were situated on the surrounding terraces, on the floodplain and in the uplands

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Seasonal campsites and special- activity sites may have continued to be located on the terraces and floodplains, and on the uplands, respectively

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: The Late Archaic is reportedly distinguishable by the predominant usage of local lithic raw materials (Crook and Harris 1954), presumably consisting of local river terrace quartzites

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Seasonal campsites continued to be located on the first terraces and the floodplains, hunting camps were along small drainages on the uplands, and fishing and musselling stations were on the floodplains next to the larger creeks and rivers

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: An optimum settlement site is determined by an individual on the basis of cultural as well as environmental factors, including but not limited to: access to a water source; desirability of land for agricultural pursuits; availability of building materials; familiarity with topography and soil; access to transportation and communication networks; known climatic factors associated with the site of the area (e

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: In the case of Upland South immigrants into the Lake Ray Roberts area, certain site preferences may be suggested

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Less is known about midwesterners' site preferences with relation to a grid system that is not completely linear, however it seems likely that midwestern immigrants also preferred hilltop locations, upland topograph) and proximity to roads

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Second, archaeological literature and maps of topography and soils were used to identify land forms most likely to contain sites so that special attention would be given to these areas during the field survey

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Wide intervals (up to 50 m) were used in uplands and upland slopes where ground cover was sparse, probability of prehistoric sites was low, and historic standing structures and archaeological features were clearly visible

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: All too often the use of environmental variables for examining prehistoric settlement has resulted in spurious conclusions such as "water was of prime importance to early man," or that "soil type accounts for a small proportion of the variability discerned in site location

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Indeed, it is often the case that the more disturbed a site is by modern plowing or gravel quarrying, the large and, thus, more representative the overall surface artifact sample is, although estimations of site size and internal structure are certainly less reliable

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: All of these sites are situated on lower terraces very close to water sources in the form of the larger creeks

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Like the Type I sites, almost all of these Type 2a sites are located on lower terraces close to the large stream channels

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: As with the two previous types of sizes, Type 2b sites seem generally to be located close to water on major streams, and on lower terraces

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Type 2c sites appear to be confined to the edges of the lower terraces, very close to the major stream systems

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: All of these sites fall into the existing pattern for site location already discerned, being located along the major watercourses on the lower terraces

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: In some cases, they are located on low terraces or rises close to major water sources in the same kind of situation that characterizes what are apparently more permanent seasonal campsites or base camps

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: In many instances, however, they are located farther away from water sources on the higher terraces and upland slopes, presumably a reflection of their more limited occupation and decreased concern with reliable water sources

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Site 41GS102 is located on the edge of a lower terrace, close to Buck Creek

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: The former site is located on the edge of an upper terrace and is 0

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: The site is located on the edge of the uplands above the south bank of Buck Creek

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: The site is located on the edge of an upper terrace above Indian Creek, and presumably was associated functionally with the cluster of prehistoric sites in that area

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: All of these sites are located along the Elm Fork in the southern part of the project area, on low terraces, very close to the mainstream channel

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Site 41DNI75 is located at the edge of a lower terrace moderately close to the mainstream channel

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: All of these sites are situated in the floodplain of the major river courses, adjoining smaller drainages

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Only four sites have been classified as being Type 4d sites (41DN79, 81, 82; and 41CO139) and three of these are close enough to represent seasonal reoccupations of the same general terrace edge

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: In terms of site location, the larger sites are located on top of a lower terrace overlooking a small tributary of the Elm Fork, and on the floodplain next to the Elm Fork further North

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: The smaller site is located on the floodplain of that channel, as was the case for all of the Type 4c sites

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: All three of these sites are located along Isle du Bois Creek, or one of its tributaries, in the eastern side of the project area, and would have had access to the quartzite gravels in this area

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Related largely to the limited nature of the assemblages from these sites, and the fact that they are all located on eroded gravel slopes, Type 6b sites have been placed with Type 6a sites as lithic procurement sites

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: All of these sites are situated on the edges of eroded gravel deposits associated with terraces in the southeastern lake area, and most do not appear to be associated with anything which could be considered permanent water sources

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: All of these sites are located on the uplands or terraces and are associated with gravel deposits

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Close-up of primary lithic debris scattered among TI gravels on this lithic workshop site

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: This gap can be explained by noting that the majority of prehistoric sites (and site clusters) are situated so as to have maximum access to both upland and lowland environments

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: What prehistoric sites have been identified along this drainage are generally on tributaries or on the upland edges above the floodplain, and in several cases outside the limits of the lake

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: This situation is probably the result of two factors: (1) the lack of preservation of surface sites within the Elm Fork floodplain; and (2) an actual lack of any large permanent camps or seasonal base camps within the bulk of the floodplain

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: In regard to the second factor, it should be noted that the sites located within the floodplain of the Elm Fork, or its tributary, Spring Creek, appear to be seasonal collecting or musselling camps (the ones along Spring Creek and at the northern margin of the lake may have been utilized over a relatively long period of time), while no lower terrace remnants or knolls have been identified within the floodplain which would have been suitabie lot permanent or semi-permanent occupation

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: The areas where prehistoric remains or artifacts have been identified along the upper portion of the Elm Fork are closely associated with several large areas of Pleistocene terrace deposits along the west side of the Elm Fork, but largely beyond the limits of the Lake Ray Roberts flood pool

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: These remains may be associated with larger, more permanent campsites located to the west of the Elm Fork, on top of the large terrace deposits mentioned above

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: A hint that such a pattern may exist is given by the verbal identification of a reportedly large site, on top of one of these terraces, above Spring Creek

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Remnants of the T2 terrace system, believed to possibly contain Paleo-Indian material based on finds at the site of Lewisville to the south, were identified geologically (see Chapter III) and carefully examined with similar negative results

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Another factor suggesting the unlikelihood of identifying Paleo-Indian sites on these higher terraces is their overall distance from sources of permanent water in the form of the modern stream channels

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: The more likely locations for Paleo-Indian sites, closer to the water channels, have been wiped out by later erosion and terrace formation

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: , the TI terrace consisted of the floodplain and would presumably have been less attractive to permanent occupation than was the case at a later point in time

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: More ephemeral occupations within the floodplain (the TI terrace of today) would have left sparse remains and are unlikely to have survived until the present

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: All of these sites appear to be associated with terrace or upland margins, with the exceptions of 41CO20 and the unidentified SMU site, X41CO16, both of which appear to be located within the area of the Isle du Bois floodplain, possibly on a terrace remnant

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: These site locations suggest that occupation occurred following the final stabilization of the TI terrace system around 5000 to 4500 B

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: The close association of this site with the Isle du Bois floodplain suggests a late date of occupation within the Middle Archaic period (probably after 1000 B

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: Thus, for example, an eroded lithic procurement site located on an upper terrace may safely be recommended as requiring no further work, in consideration that the few lithic workshops in similar situations tested elsewhere proved to have no depth and small artifact samples

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md
relationships.text: On the other hand, a marginally eroded base camp that occupies a large lower terrace, most of which is undisturbed, may be reasonably recommended as requiring systematic testing, in consideration of the results of testing at other such sites elsewhere, where a long history of occupation along with trash pits and burials has been revealed

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1982 - Archeology and History of Lake Ray Roberts v1.md

relationships.text: ArcheologicalJournaloftheTexasPrairie-Savannah 2(1) BURNED CLAY OBJECTS FROM SITE 41DL238, DALLAS COUNTY, TEXAS PaulLorrain INTRODUCTION Sitescontainingfiredor burnedclayobjectsvariouslydescribed aslumps, ballsor blobs are frequently reported from sites in Southeast (Turpin 2004) and North Central Texas (Wilson 2009)

relationships.file: 00 AJC-Journal-2012.md
relationships.text: DISCUSSION An archeological site containing the burned clay objects is 41DL238 in Dallas County

relationships.file: 00 AJC-Journal-2012.md
relationships.text: CONCLUSIONS No more than a few dozen burned clay objects have been reported from sites in the Upper Trinity River Watershed and all range from Early to Middle Archaic in age (Crook 2009)

relationships.file: 00 AJC-Journal-2012.md
relationships.text: The amount of Late Archaic points in the vicinity of site 41DL238 may suggestthatburnedclayobjectsintheDallasCountyarea, aswellas North CentralTexas maybemoreplentifuland youngerthanpreviouslyrecognized

relationships.file: 00 AJC-Journal-2012.md
relationships.text: Engraving was done with a sharp tool when the vessel was either leather-hard or after it was fired, while the other decorative techniques were executed with tools or fingers (incising and punctations with wood or bone sticks or dowels), or byusing frayed sticks or grass stems (brushing) across the vessel surface when the vessel was wet In one instance, a sherd from 41BL1110 has evidence of the application of a hematite-rich clay slip or red wash

relationships.file: 00 AJC-Journal-2012.md
relationships.text: The clay wash was typically applied to one or both surfaces in this prehistoric Central and South Texas ceramic ware, and then was burnished after it was leather-hard or dry; whenthevesselwas fired,itcreated averythinredcoatingontheexterior vesselsurface

relationships.text: =engraved;B=brushed;B-I=brushed-incised;I=incised Temper:b=bone;h=hematite;g=grogorfiredclay;o=organics;SP=sandypaste ST=surfacetreatment:I=interior;E=exterior;SM=smoothed;B=burnished/floated FC=firingcondition(seeTeltser1993;Perttula2005):A,oxidizing;B,reducing;C-E, incompletelyoxidized;F-H,reducing,butcooledinahighoxidizingenvironment;I- L=incompletelyoxidized,possiblysmudged;X=multipleoxidizedandreducedbandsinthesherd coresection TH=thickness Approximately half of the sherds from the Bowmer site excavations are from a single vessel (either a bowl or a carinated bowl) found in the main block (referred to hereafter as Vessel 1)

relationships.file: 00 AJC-Journal-2012.md
relationships.text: VesselConstruction Based on the breakage patterns of the sherds, the pottery from the Bowmer site was made using clay coils

relationships.file: 00 AJC-Journal-2012.md
relationships.text: ” That the bone temper in the Bowmer site ceramic sherds was fine to medium-textured suggests that the clay used for vessel manufacture was not particularly fine-grained or highly plastic as that documented by Johnson (1994) from various Toyah phasesitesincentralTexas

relationships.file: 00 AJC-Journal-2012.md
relationships.text: One plain sherd has small pieces of fired clay or grog temper (see Table 3) along with fine or moderate amounts of bone temper

relationships.file: 00 AJC-Journal-2012.md
relationships.text: Whether these pieces represent deliberately added crushed sherd fragments—as is so commonly seen in East Texas Caddo ceramic wares—or incidental inclusions incorporated in the clay paste during its preparation for vessel manufacture has not been determined

relationships.file: 00 AJC-Journal-2012.md
relationships.text: Perhaps the potters of this bone-grog-tempered vessel recognized that the addition of grog or fired clayto the vessel paste slowed the oxidation process during firing, creating darker-colored vessels in a reducing firing environment (or lighter tan, orange, and brown colors in oxidizing environments), while allowing them to be fired longer, and producing a harder ceramic vessel (Rice 1987:354; Teltser 1993:532, 540)

relationships.file: 00 AJC-Journal-2012.md
relationships.text: Since grog has expansion coefficients generally comparable to the coefficients of the clay paste most commonly seen in aboriginal pottery vessels, this would have contributed further to the ability of fired vessels to withstand heat-related stresses, as well as increasing their flexural strength (Rice1987:362)

relationships.file: 00 AJC-Journal-2012.md

relationships.text: I In the region of the survey, the vast majority of recorded Paleoindian sites are located on terraces with about two-thirds on tributaries and one-third on the Elm Fork channel itself (Prikryl 1990:68)

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: This bias toward terrace sites may be a reflection of the lack of investigation of deeply buried floodplain sites

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Sites buried within the floodplain are likely to go undetected during traditional survey unless the site has I been eroded or exposed in some manner

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Although this is particularly true of older sites, sites from all periods may lie undiscovered beneath the surface of the floodplain

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Furthermore, as with the I preceding period, most of the known sites are located on terraces, probably reflecting a lack of floodplain investigations

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Terraces still dominate the known I site locations, but again, this is probably due to the fact that cultural materials are easily exposed on the eroded terraces while deeply buried floodplain sites lie undiscovered

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md

relationships.text: I SUMMARY OF RECORDED SITES ALONG DENTON CREEK I The many surveys along Denton Creek by DAS members from the 1940s to the present, as well as other researchers from the University of North Texas (UNT), and SMU, have resulted in the recording of numerous sites both in the floodplain and on terraces overlooking the creek

relationships.text: Furthermore, all of the materials used to define these I cultural strata were subsistence remains (bone and mussel) or occupation debris (charcoal, burned rock fragment, burned clay) rather than artifacts

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: I Bulk soil samples from the upper two original cultural zones exposed in the ditch slopes were radiocarbon dated to 1250 ± 70 B

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: It was during these investigations that a third cultural zone was identified I about 5 meters below the present ground surface with the bulk soil radiocarbon dated to 3240 ± 70 B

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: However, I the Pleistocene terrace to the north and east of the creek probably demarcated the site boundaries (Anthony et al

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: While the eastern boundary of the site was not established due to the depth of the deposits, it can at least be safely said that the Pleistocene terrace deposits to the north and east of the exposed portion of 41DL270, visible on both USGS topographic I maps and aerial photographs, are the likely limits of the buried portion of the site, although it may have extended up onto this terrace

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Farther to the east, the structures extend onto I Pleistocene terrace deposits within which the site will not be found

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Careful analysis of lithostratigraphic units in the terrace sediments coupled with radiocarbon dating of cultural charcoal, wood, bone, and other materials from these strata provide the best method of determining the period of site occupation

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Chipped stone materials recovered from 41DL270 are generally thought to be from Trinity River gravels located a relatively short distance from the site

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: These include gastropod fauna, other molluscan I fauna, and osteological materials from the site, as well as the soil matrix within which the site is found

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: I STRATIGRAPIDC INVESTIGATIONS I Because the site lies buried in the alluvium of Denton Creek, it was considered imperative to understand the depositional and post-depositional history of the sediments at the site

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Soil samples were collected from each zone within each trench

relationships.text: Brief descriptions of the soil profile zones are presented below

relationships.text: It should be noted that the term I "soil zone" used throughout this chapter is simply a convenience referring to sections of the entire "soil profile" and is not meant to imply that pedogenic development has occurred in each zone

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: I Considerable evidence of pedogenic activity was noted in the trenches; several of the soil zones could probably be designated as pedostratigraphic units or even paleosols

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Nonetheless, comparison of the soils in these trenches does not indicate a single clear and obvious "West Fork" paleosol as appears I to be visible in soil profiles exposed by Prikryl (1992) in his investigations at the site in conjunction with National Register nomination

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: I Finally, although the terrace and floodplain/lower terrace segments at the site are clearly Holocene, there is also possible evidence for an older alluvial fill unit buried within the Late Holocene terrace

relationships.text: When flow begins to slacken, the flood waters are no longer sufficiently turbulent to hold even fine-textured sediment in suspension, I causing a veneer of laminated very fine sand, silt, and clay to be deposited, usually in that order

relationships.text: Perring (1988: 12, 17), in discussing Village Creek, a tributary of the West Fork of the Trinity in neighboring eastern Tarrant I County, concluded that thick clays of the modern floodplain (his Holocene terrace) probably were deposited, in part, under slack-water conditions in the aftermath of flooding along the Trinity River

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: In order to facilitate the analysis of changing I patterns through time, a series of arbitrary cultural zones was created, based on the assumption that cultural stratigraphy at the site was, like the general stratigraphic trend of the terrace section, horizontal or roughly flat lying across the site (although some of the surfaces on which features occurred were I observed to slope to the south and east, the amount of slope was measured in a few centimeters; thus the 113 I I

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: I Note that, with the exception of the area investigated in the gully leading to the creek, all of the zones are stratigraphically related in the Late Holocene terrace fill

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Based on several radiocarbon dates and interpretation of the general stratigraphy of the site, this lower terrace or floodplain area in the gully I has been included with Cultural Zone I, the highest in the Late Holocene terrace fill

relationships.text: 1· Non-local in this case refers not only to a lack of a particular material in the collections of 41DL270, but also material not thought to be within a few miles of the site or within the Ogallala gravels

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: I Lithic Material The vast majority of the material is from Ogallala-derived gravels - quartzite and a coarse-grained I chert most often tan in color, and an unidentified material referred to as "other"

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Of major significance to the North-Central Texas region within which 41DL270 is located is the widespread yet localized occurrence of redeposited Ogallala gravels (source) containing quartzites and cherts (resource)

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Banks (1990) refers to such sites as "workshop-site types" and states that they are most often found on or near I gravel deposits

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: I As if lithic resource identification of in situ cherts were not complicated enough, the Uvalde Gravel certainly provides an added dimension to the complexities in many parts of Texas and I elsewhere

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Despite the author's apparently incorrect assertion that the Ogallala materials represent an I in situ Ogallala Formation lag deposit extending as far east as the Dallas area rather than alluvially redeposited gravels (Caran, personal communication 1994), they provide a wealth of information on the actual gravels

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Important to the study of 41DL270, one of the upland collection locations in the Menzer and Slaughter study was from the northwest comer of Dallas County at Northlake, within a stone's throw, I so to speak, of the site

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Local, chert is found within the redeposited gravels whose locations, as mentioned above, are sporadic

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: More important to the percentage than the antiquity of the sites, however, was the distance of the sites from upland gravel sources

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Sites closer to upland gravel sources tended to have higher percentages of chert and, conversely, I lower percentages of chert were found at those sites located farther from upland gravels

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Finally, data from some of the sites and upland gravel localities suggested the possibility that chert sources had been depleted through long utilization

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: An examination of natural gravel resources showed lower percentages I of chert at procurement localities near defined archeological sites

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The reconnaissance along the upper and middle Trinity River for the proposed Tennessee Colony Lake I in the mid-1970s recorded 72 out of 73 shell lens sites in the cutbanks of the floodplains (Richner 1978:246)

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The remaining lens site was located on a T2 terrace

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Several important sites, however, such as the Butler Hole Site, are apparently terrace locations

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Within the Denton Creek drainage, those sites I with recorded mussel shell concentrations are either on the creek bank, the floodplain, or the terrace edge adjacent to it, except for two sites on the lower and upper terraces north of the creek (41DN290, now destroyed, and 41DN480, respectively)

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: At Adams Ranch, 41NV177, the site itself lies on several I surfaces including a high Pleistocene terrace while Feature 1 appears to have been dug into a lower surface which could possibly be a lower terrace or the floodplain of the creek

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The Cobb-Pool site, 41D1148, offers a good comparison between a terrace habitation site and a floodplain occupation site in I its mussel shell processing and discard patterns

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The authors doubted this feature was actually a hearth because the sandstone and shells were only slightly burned and there was only a small amount of the charcoal and ash mentioned above

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: At the Butler Hole site mentioned above, the mussel shells surrounding the slightly burned sandstone feature were charred

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Prikryl and Perring (1987: 107) note that the floodplain stability and soil formation at the site appear to correlate with proposed moister climates of I the first millennium A

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: They point out a Late Holocene dry-moist-dry cycle for the Southern Plains, with the intermediate moist phase expressed as a period of greater effective moisture with associated high water tables, I floodplain aggradation, and the development of a paleosol between A

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The main portion of the site, lying along the east bank of the artificial drainage ditch, is an alluvial terrace of Denton Creek whose uppermost fill, at least, dates to the Late I Holocene

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Because of the intensity of cultural occupation at the site during the development of the Late Holocene terrace, however, it is assumed that a channel of the creek was also near the site

relationships.text: More bulk soil or humate dates from the site would add to the analysis but the general lack of precision of such methods argues for the search for other methods of dating

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: A limited set of experiments were conducted at 41DL270 with sandstone recovered from suspected hearths at the site, much like those conducted at the Camp Pearl Wheat site (Collins et al

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: I In addition to his work with the orientation of the rock samples, Gose studied the magnetic susceptibility of soil samples collected from the site

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Of all the cultural features recorded in the Late Holocene alluvial terrace at the site, only two I features and a few isolated artifacts were noted above or below this zone

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Unfortunately there is no way at present to certainly determine if the increase in human activity in this level at the site is due to actual increased population density, I increased utilization of the floodplains at this time, or, as suggested by this study, a combination of these with a slight slowing of deposition and at least the brief initiation of pedogenic processes

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: On the eroded bank, the vast majority of features have a substantial component of sandstone

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Finally, as noted above, there are still few chronometric I dates from the site, and most of these are on bulk soil or soil humates, potentially unreliable materials

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: ) • Zone 1-F designates the floodplain area while 1-T designates the upper terrace area

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: I terrace do not evidence a long-term or semi-permanent occupation, it may be that the nearby Pleistocene terrace (now destroyed) held a larger base camp

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: Cultural materials have been noted on the Pleistocene I terrace remnant near the new Highway 121 bridge (a kilometer or so from 41DL270) by Bill Young (personal communication 1992, and TARL site files)

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The temporal span of the site can roughly be correlated with geomorphic trends (see above for correlation with paleoclimatic trends) in that these occupations may be generally contemporaneous with the formation of the terrace

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: The greatest number of occupations of the site may well have occurred while the terrace was actively forming rather than while it offered a stable surface

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: In general, it is felt likely that the use of humate and bulk soil dates I may offer ages which are slightly older than the actual date (this is apparently the case with the Godley point which seems to be dated a bit too old, but it may have moved downward on the bank as well)

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: No ground stone was found at the site, despite the fact that Woodbine sandstone, a potentially excellent material for grinding implements (and used for such at many prehistoric sites), was quite common in the burned rock features at the site and is probably available in I local stream gravel outcrops or even in sandstone bedrock outcrops to the west

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: As noted there, it is not possible to determine the exact source of the lithic materials utilized at the site, but most are available within the locally abundant terrace gravels which derive ultimately from the Ogallala formation of West Texas

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: I Whether these gravels were found on the now destroyed Pleistocene terrace remnant adjacent to the site or on recently quarried terrace remnants that lie across the creek to the northwest, or whether they came from some greater distance simply cannot be stated with confidence

relationships.file: 00 Anthony and Brown 1994 - 41DL270 Data Recovery.md
relationships.text: This point is I manufactured from a chert-like material that is not found in the local terrace gravels and probably, like the point itself, comes from some distance to the east of the project area

relationships.file: Shipp et al 2019 - Mercado Site 41TR203.md
relationships.text: A series of Analytical Units (AUs), representing well-preserved, temporally and culturally distinct prehistoric occupations that occurred on the river terraces of the West Fork of the Trinity River, were identified using multiple lines of archeological and geomorphic data, including microstratigraphy

relationships.text: Burned Earth The analysis of the artifact assemblage of the materials recovered by the excavation of 41TR203 identified two morphological variants of burned clay in the artifact assemblage: 1) platy fiber impressed fragments; and 2) irregular rounded objects

relationships.file: Shipp et al 2019 - Mercado Site 41TR203.md
relationships.text: The geoarcheological study (see Chapter 6) documented three forms of burned earth: 1) in-situ thermal rubified rims associated with thermal features; 2) small fragments of burned earth presumed to have been detached from the baked earth of thermal features (presumably scatted by cleaning out hearths and other features); and 3) platy, apparently sand-tempered objects

relationships.file: Shipp et al 2019 - Mercado Site 41TR203.md

relationships.text: River Legacy Park Archaeology INTRODUCTION The Rough Green site (4 1 TRI 62) is a prehistoric archaeological campsite that was encountered during the archaeological survey of a wastewater pipeline that crosses the floodplain of the West Fork of the Trinity River (Figure 1)

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: No evidence was found of historic or prehistoric sites on the floodplain surface

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Av ocational archeologist Bill Young surveyed the area north and east of the project area over a number of years and recorded sites located primarily on the northern terraces of the West Fork (Young 1992)

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Young's site TA9 is a large lithic scatter and possible Uvalde Gravel quarry that was immediately south of Mosier Valley Road across from the southern boundary of the Euless Sports Complex (Whorton and Skinner 1995)

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: This site has now been destroyed by sand and gravel mining

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: In 1994, the Archaeology Research Program (ARP) of Mercyhurst College recorded two sites (4 1 TRI 41 and 142) east of the project area within the floodplain and north of the West Fork of the Trinity River (Shaunessy, Jurney, and Yedlowski 1994: 1)

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Testing at site 41 TRI 41 yielded a Middle to Late Archaic Palmillas dart point, as well as other artifactual and ecofactual materials_ Subsequent testing of site 41 TRI 42 and other floodplain deposits for buried cultural horizons was conducted in 1996 by Geoarch Consultants (Perring and Byers 1996)

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Testing revealed the presence of an abandoned meanderbelt system in the floodplain west of site 41TR142_ The site was shown to contain a preserved Late Archaic deposit over an area of about 20,500 square meters

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: The floodplain site is considered to be the largest such site in the West Fork below Lake Bridgeport (Perring and Byers 1996:12)

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: A thick section of Pilot Point alluvium is above the Sanger and is topped with a soil referred to as the West Fork Paleosol

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: The site is an extensive lithic scatter located on a high terrace on the east side of Village Creek

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Surface artifacts generally come from deposits on stream terraces above the level of the active floodplain

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: During the Early Archaic, rapid alluviation is equated with a wet period, and sites are found on stream terraces

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: On the Elm Fork, Prikryl (1990:71) reports fewer bottomland sites than during the Middle Archaic while sites are predominantly found on the first terrace above stream floodplains

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: These data were important, since it was anticipated that occupation was on a seasonal basis and from this we anticipated reconstructing scheduling ventures to the West Fork floodplain, selection of site locations, and population size projections

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Likewise, the selection of deposits representing brief occupations allowed for the definition of the unique activities present in the deposits in the West Fork floodplain

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: The following hypotheses guided the field investigations, artifact analyses, and site interpretations: It was hypothesized that the individual occupations at sites 41 TR 162 and 164 represented short-term occupations at campsites located in the floodplain of the West Fork of the Trinity River for the primary purpose of gathering [harvesting

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: The most prominent food resource at these sites was freshwater mussels, while at the same time, the family groups that occupied the camps gathered other riverine/floodplain plant and animal resources

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Marrow extraction, as reflected in bone breakage, may provide a measure of occupation permanence, or lack thereof, when compared to samples from other excavated floodplain sites on Mountain Creek, such as Baggett Branch

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Plant remains, particularly walnuts and pecans, were likely to have been harvested in the fall at these sites, although it is possible that mast harvesting was done at different times of the year than when the mussels were collected, and might have been done as a day foraging activity from more permanent seasonal camps or base camps located away from the river channel in the uplands or along tributaries

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Intra-site features would include stone-lined hearths or possibly burned clay and ash/charcoal which mark the locations of unprepared fireplaces [hearths] surrounded by small accumulations of discarded mussel shells and fire-cracked rock

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: It was anticipated that floral and faunal materials, sealed in features by subsequent flooding/silting, would provide seasonal information as was done at the Baggett Branch site on a broader scale

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Based on the apparent high number of mussel shells, the low number of animal bones, and the virtual absence of lithics, it was concluded that the site represented brief occupations of the floodplain for the purpose of harvesting freshwater mussels

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: The geomorphology of the deeper deposit at site 41 TR164 indicated that occupation was earlier than that at site 41 TRl 62, and it was determined that testing the deeply buried deposit and having the soil and shells from the deep horizon radiocarbon dated were important to understanding the archaeology of the West Fork floodplain

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Discussion Excavation of the Rough Green site revealed a buried deposit that is concentrated in 30- 40 cm of sediment buried under the floodplain of the West Fork of the Trinity River and adjacent to an abandoned meander that is significantly shallower than the present river channel

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: However, the probable pedoturbation that occurs in terrace sites such as Fountain has apparently mixed the limited late Late Prehistoric artifact assemblage with the more prominent earlier component(s); this presents a challenging opportunity for the archaeologists who are reporting this important multi-year investigation

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: However, the presence of occupation surfaces at numerous floodplain sites at Lake Ray Roberts (Ferring and Yates 1997:47- 199) and at Joe Pool Lake emphasize the potential of excavating blocks in such sites

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: The primary use of chert lithic debris agrees with findings at surrounding sites Joe Pool Lake, Lake Lewisville, and Lake Ray Roberts where the use of cherts from upland gravel shields and possibly regional cherts (Ferring and Yates 1997:29) and demonstrates that the lithic debris sample from Rough Green conforms with the pattern of contemporaneous sites in this part of North-Central Texas

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: However, the lack of additional post holes in the area surrounding the lone post hole in Block 3 and the scattered presence of burned clay throughout the aggrading levee fill lead to the conclusion that occupation was brief and may have lasted a few days at a time

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Environmental indicators including charcoal, gastropods, animal bones, and leaf impressions on burned clay indicate that the floodplain environment did not change significantly during the occupation period

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Radiocarbon and Carbon Stable-Isotope Analyses Excavation and description of the stratigraphic profile at site 41 TRI 64 revealed a variety of potentially datable materials in a series of soil horizons associated with nondiagnostic AR Consultants

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Volatile: The organic carbon component of soil humate that is volatilized when the sample undergoes argon-tube pyrolysis

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Non-volatile: The organic carbon component of soil humate that is not volatilized when the sample undergoes argon-tube pyrolysis

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: or near this point (Y-intercept of TT8-5 ITS-I linear equation ~O Soil humates Mollusc shells and X=O)

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Volatile components consist of organic acids that are light, mobile, and easily translocated through the soil profile

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: In many cases, the age of the non-volatile component is assumed to approximate the time of deposition of the parent material, whereas the age of the volatile component provides an estimate of the time of soil formation

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Calcareous nodules (pedoconcretions) in soils are yet another two-component material consisting of inorganic carbon in calcium carbonate and organic matter trapped between mineral layers and within individual crystals

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: The volatile components may have derived early in the development of a given soil horizon and remained essentially fixed because of the high clay content, high bulk density, and low transmissivity of the soil

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: The clear discrepancy in the ages of the humate and nodule components, however, denotes that organic components were translocated through the soil at different times

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Soil development continued preferentially in permeable zones until 2000 BP

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: The 613C ratio of the organic component of sample 8-2 was the most depleted of all of these samples and, therefore, closest to the expected value of the C vegetation dominating the site during 3 post-depositional soil development

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: This observation appears to corroborate the finding that the organic component of sample 8-2 includes material added long after deposition of the mineral sediment composing the soil horizon from which the sample was collected

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: The inferred radiocarbon chronology of deposition and soil development at this site is consistent with the degree of horizonation particularly the common, hard, granule- to pebble-size calcareous nodules below 219 cm depth and the argillic horizon below 301 cm depth--based on observations elsewhere in the region (Caran, 1990a, 1990b; Ferring, 1988, 1990)

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: However, the dates from the two sites and the history of deposition described above indicate that this meander was present for several thousand years, and that recently it was abandoned

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: In the light of this evidence, it is our purpose to propose that these sites, and probably others known and unknown in the floodplain of the West Fork of the Trinity River, served as an extended family camp from which bur oak (Quercus macrocarpa) acorns were gathered

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Numerous bur oaks (Figure 24) are present today in the floodplain between the two sites and throughout the surrounding bottomland hardwood forest

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: The problem is that the River Legacy Park sites are not located miles upstream from the floodplain· of the West Fork of the Trinity, and thus are not in analogous places to the Baggett Branch site

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: It is our belief that many of the generalized or apparently unfocused temporary/seasonal hunting and gathering campsites described within the floodplain of the West Fork served as the center point for the gathering of acorns from family oak groves

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: River Legacy Park Archaeology 71 Pleistocene terraces [Qt] are shown as a separate zone [d iagonally lined areas on Figure 25], except where the terrace area is laterally small and does not show well on a reduced map and where sites are not known to be present

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: This zone is generally above river flooding and supports a prairie or a forested environment depending upon the terrace location

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: The terrace zone includes settings that are adjacent to major and minor drainages

relationships.file: 00 Skinner et al 1999 - River Legacy Park.md
relationships.text: Access to adjacent environmental zones highlights the importance of the terrace zone

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: Bottomland communities along the major river and creek drainages contain a diverse hardwood and swamp forest (including cypress, tupelo, and sweet gum), with natural levees and alluvial terraces, point bar deposits, old stream channels, oxbow lakes, and backwater swamps

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: The parent material of soils found within the Park is either alluvial (deposited by rivers or streams) or marine

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: The research potential of archeological sites occurring in Sandy Mantle contexts has been disputed (see Lohse and Bousman [2006:60–63] for a synopsis)

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: static and non-aggrading) found in East Texas Sandy Mantle areas, and the degree of translocation of archeological materials by biological mixing found in such settings, generally meet a reasonable contextual threshold for determining site integrity and contain interpretable samples of archeological materials

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: These conditions may also have influenced changes to the landscape brought about by significant erosion (and the transportation of sandy sediments), stream downcutting, and the formation, preservation, or degradation of landforms that contain, or once contained, traces of human occupation

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: At the Forrest Murphey site (41MR62), for example, Clovis, Plainview, Dalton, and other lanceolate projectile point forms and tools were found in several discrete concentrations on a high terrace above Big Cypress Creek; faunal remains from extinct elephants, a rather rare occurrence, were also recovered in apparent association (Story 1990)

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: For example, a provocative but poorly known Paleoindian site has been reported by avocational archeologists in deep sand deposits on the Neches River, where it had been exposed by Lake Palestine shoreline erosion

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: In another case, McCrocklin (1994 personal communication) has documented Dalton and early side-notched Big Sandy points, knives, scrapers, bone tools (antler flakers), and cut bone (some fossilized) from blue clay deposits buried in a Red River gravel bar north of Shreveport, Louisiana

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: Anderson (1996a) suggests that such Archaic groups had highly mobile foraging adaptations along the Red River, the central Sabine River, and in interior uplands away from major drainages, with expedient lithic technologies

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: To the south of the Sabine River, but concentrated in the Neches-Angelina and Attoyac drainage basins, Woodland period sites contain plain sandy paste ceramics (Goose Creek Plain, var

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: Changes in the density and placement of Woodland period sites across the landscape—particularly focusing on sandy interfluves—led Corbin (1998:114–115) to suggest that horticulture may have been introduced in the Neches-Angelina river basins during the Woodland period

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: , plants that were restricted to valley margins and/or the floodplain) whose use was facilitated by processing via cooking in ceramic vessels

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: Caddo sites of Formative to Middle Caddo period age are situated primarily on elevated landforms (alluvial terraces and rises, natural levees, and upland edges) adjacent to the major streams, as well as along minor tributaries and spring-fed branches

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: Davis site (Story 1997, 1998, 2000) and a few other mound centers (such as Washington Square [41NA49)], Boxed Springs, and Sanders [41LR2]; see Corbin and Hart 1998; Hamilton 1997), and they also occur in non-mound contexts at several sites along the Red River during Formative period (see Bruseth 1998)

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: The Musgano site (41RK19) is also a Middle Caddo habitation site that was located on an upland landform not far from Martin Creek, and is now an island in Martin Creek Lake

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: Well-made, corner-notched, and rectangular-stemmed arrow points were common, along with siltstone and greenstone celts, perforators and borers, large Gahagan bifaces, and a variety of more expedient stone tools (unifacial flake scraping and cutting implements)

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: The earliest types of Caddo clay pipes were plain, tubular and cigar-shaped forms, followed by the long-stem “Red River” pipes (Hoffman 1967) with burnished and polished stems and bowls; rectangular platform pipes and some elbow pipe forms have also been recovered in Caddo sites dating before A

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: In at least two instances, the mounds contained sequent structures, but the “structures originated at higher levels in the mound[s] due to occupational accumulations of soil and ash, and not the result of any deliberate capping” (Thurmond 1990:168)

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: Soils were screened through a 1/4-inch mesh screen to recover any artifacts in the soil matrix; all cultural materials were collected from the shovel tests that produced artifacts

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: The sparse distribution of prehistoric sites or components in the Park area is likely the consequence of the limited distribution of permanent water sources in upland areas

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: (2009:227) noted the same low density of prehistoric sites in upland areas in the nearby Rusk Permit Area, commenting that “[w]ith springs present but not frequent along and at the heads of intermittent, mostly runoff-fed drainages, this area lacks places that would have been suitable for intensive occupation by Native Americans

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: Backhoe Investigations Considering the general upland setting of Martin Creek Lake State Park, only one area within the Park was identified where potential artifact-bearing sediments more than 100 cm in depth are present (see Figure 8)

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: Backhoe trench investigations may be warranted in this locale for two principal archeological reasons: (1) to ascertain and clarify the depth, thickness, and depositional context of deep sandy sediments that may contain deep artifact-bearing sediments; and (2) to prospect for other archeological sites that are deeply buried and have no near-surface expression

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: Backhoe trench investigations in this locale may also be warranted to contribute archeological and geoarcheological information from Martin Creek Lake State Park on the research issue of “whether prehistoric sites can occur in a primary context buried within the so- called sandy mantle” (Crawford and Nordt 2001:17; see also Lohse and Bousman 2006)

relationships.file: Perttula et al. 2011 - Arch Investigations at Martin Creek Lake State Park.md
relationships.text: These alternatives have implications for interpreting the depositional integrity and research potential of sandy mantle sites, and bear on the likely research significance of any sandy mantle sites at Martin Creek Lake State Park

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2015 - Pleasant Valley Road.md
relationships.text: Burned Clay Masses of burned or baked clay are common at prehistoric sites in Northcentral Texas and surrounding regions

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2015 - Pleasant Valley Road.md
relationships.text: Burned clay may be found as massive, fused deposits enclosing hearths or cooking pits (Osburn and Ward 2007), shaped or rounded nodules that served as boiling “stones” (Ford and Webb 1956), fallen wattle-and-daub structures (Boyd 2004b), fallen plastered thatch structures (Drass 2008), intrusive or local material deliberately or accidentally trampled into a living surface, masses introduced into a living area on collected plant roots (Goldberg 2008), insect nests that can sometimes be considered as proxy indicators of human occupation (Boyd 2004b), or as evidence of forest fires with no direct indication of human activity

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2015 - Pleasant Valley Road.md
relationships.text: Previous investigations at site 41DL203 identified the possibility of multiple types and functions of burned clay objects and included experimental studies to replicate some of the hypothesized phenomena (Tinsley and Dayton 2011:102–117)

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2015 - Pleasant Valley Road.md
relationships.text: Results of the experimental studies suggest that much of the burned clay recovered at the site is likely due to the use of fired clay balls as heating elements in hearths or for stone boiling, a common pre-ceramic cooking technique, in an environment where readily-available stone is relatively scarce (Tinsley and Dayton 2011:111)

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2015 - Pleasant Valley Road.md
relationships.text: No intact burned clay features were encountered during the current investigations at site 41DL203

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2015 - Pleasant Valley Road.md
relationships.text: Many burned clay masses encountered during the current investigation were poorly hardened or extensively reworked by taphonomic processes indicating that this artifact class is probably underrepresented due to mechanical disintegration during the recovery process

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2015 - Pleasant Valley Road.md
relationships.text: The recovery of this item provides anecdotal evidence that the lenticular burned clay lenses previously encountered at site 41DL203 may have been remnants of thermal features as well; however, none of these lenticular burned clay features were encountered within the currently investigated portion of the site and conclusive evidence of the functions of these features remains elusive

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2015 - Pleasant Valley Road.md
relationships.text: Within the Northcentral Texas region, chipped lithic artifacts are commonly made of locally-occurring quartzite gravels and, to a lesser extent, chert and other cryptocrystalline materials from surrounding regions

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2015 - Pleasant Valley Road.md
relationships.text: Quartzite occurs across the Northcentral Texas region in upland Tertiary gravel deposits, often termed Ogallala gravels (Ferring and Yates 1997), which are commonly redeposited in alluvial settings

relationships.file: 00 Goodmaster et al 2015 - Pleasant Valley Road.md
relationships.text: Botanical Remains Botanical remains identified on prehistoric archeological sites in Northcentral Texas are typically confined to charred plant remains recovered opportunistically within the soil matrix during excavation or during flotation of excavated soil samples
